Retrieved 22 July 2010. * A modern and updated flight simulator, which may be used for a greater fraction of pilot training in order to reduce the costly flight hours of the actual aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-works-to-bridge-gap-between-its-sustainment-cost-estimates-and-lockheeds-380967/ |title=USAF works to bridge gap between its sustainment cost estimates and Lockheed’s. |work=Flight International |date=12 January 2013 |accessdate=24 February 2013}} * Lightweight, powerful [[lithium-ion batteries]] to provide power to run the control surfaces in an emergency.{{cite web |url=http://www.dailytech.com/Pentagon+to+Use+LithiumIon+Batteries+for+F35+Jets+Despite+Boeing+787+Woes/article29896.htm |title=Pentagon to Use Lithium-Ion Batteries for F-35 Jets Despite Boeing 787 Woes. |work=Dailytech.com |accessdate=24 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130217010310/http://www.dailytech.com/Pentagon+to+Use+LithiumIon+Batteries+for+F35+Jets+Despite+Boeing+787+Woes/article29896.htm |archivedate=17 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Structural composites in the F-35 are 35% of the airframe weight (up from 25% in the F-22).{{cite web|url=http://www.compositesworld.com/articles/skinning-the-f-35-fighter|title=Skinning the F-35 fighter|author=CompositesWorld |work=compositesworld.com|accessdate=24 November 2016}} The majority of these are [[Maleimide|bismaleimide (BMI)]] and [[composite epoxy material]].[http://www.onlineamd.com/aerospace-manufacturing-design-Vector-Composites-Quicksteps-amd-051710.aspx "Contract Awarded To Validate Process For JSF"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314153109/http://www.onlineamd.com/aerospace-manufacturing-design-Vector-Composites-Quicksteps-amd-051710.aspx |date=14 March 2012 }}. ''onlineamd.com, '' 17 May 2010. Retrieved 22 July 2010. The F-35 will be the first mass-produced aircraft to include structural nanocomposites, namely [[carbon nanotube]]-reinforced [[epoxy]].Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/05/26/357223/lockheed-martin-reveals-f-35-to-feature-nanocomposite.html "Lockheed Martin reveals F-35 to feature nanocomposite structures"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110530213822/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/05/26/357223/lockheed-martin-reveals-f-35-to-feature-nanocomposite.html |date=30 May 2011 }} ''Flight International'', 26 May 2011. Experience of the F-22's problems with corrosion led to the F-35 using a gap filler that causes less [[galvanic corrosion]] to the airframe's skin, designed with fewer gaps requiring filler and implementing better drainage.Edwards, Jack E. [http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d11171r.pdf "Defense Management: DOD Needs to Monitor and Assess Corrective Actions Resulting from Its Corrosion Study of the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter"]. ''[[United States Government Accountability Office]], Washington, DC,'' 16 December 2010. The relatively short 35-foot wingspan of the A and B variants is set by the F-35B's requirement to fit inside the Navy's current amphibious assault ship parking areaRyberg, Eric S. "[http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a399988.pdf The Influence of Ship Configuration on the Design of the Joint Strike Fighter]", p. 5. ''[[Naval Surface Warfare Center Dahlgren Division]]'', 26 February 2002. Accessed: 1 December 2013. and elevators; the F-35C's longer wing is considered to be more fuel efficient.{{cite web|url=http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/The-Ultimate-Fighter-166000926.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130116143836/http://www.airspacemag.com/military-aviation/The-Ultimate-Fighter-166000926.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 January 2013 |title=The Ultimate Fighter? |work=Airspacemag.com |accessdate=24 February 2013}} A United States Navy study found that the F-35 will cost 30 to 40 percent more to maintain than current jet fighters,Clark, Colin. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/01/27/af-worries-jsf-costs-may-soar/ "AF Worries JSF Costs May Soar"]. ''DoD Buzz'' 27 January 2011. not accounting for inflation over the F-35's operational lifetime. A Pentagon study concluded a $1 trillion maintenance cost for the entire fleet over its lifespan, not accounting for inflation.Capaccio, Tony. [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-04-21/lockheed-martin-f-35-operating-costs-may-reach-1-trillion.html "Lockheed Martin F-35 Operating Costs May Reach $1 Trillion"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429000949/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-04-21/lockheed-martin-f-35-operating-costs-may-reach-1-trillion.html |date=29 April 2011 }} ''Bloomberg News'', 21 April 2011. The F-35 program office found that as of January 2014, costs for the F-35 fleet over a 53-year life cycle was $857 billion. Costs for the fighter have been dropping and accounted for the 22 percent life cycle drop since 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforcemag.com/DRArchive/Pages/2014/January%202014/January%2008%202014/The-Cost-of-Teamwork.aspx |title=The Cost of Teamwork |work=airforcemag.com |date=8 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=John A. |last=Tirpak |publisher=Air Force Association |location=Arlington, VA |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525023853/http://www.airforcemag.com/DRArchive/Pages/2014/January%202014/January%2008%202014/The-Cost-of-Teamwork.aspx |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Lockheed stated that by 2019, pricing for the fifth-generation aircraft will be less than fourth-generation fighters. An F-35A in 2019 is expected to cost $85 million per unit complete with engines and full mission systems, inflation adjusted from $75 million in December 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-touts-f-35-progress-predicts-competitive-pricing-394185/ |title=Lockheed touts F-35 progress, predicts competitive pricing |work=flightglobal.com |date=16 December 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Jon |last=Hemmerdinger |others=Photo credits: Lockheed Martin |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525024335/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-touts-f-35-progress-predicts-competitive-pricing-394185/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} === Engines === [[File:F-35A Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter Powerplant on display at Centenary of Military Aviation 2014.jpg|thumb|An F-35A powerplant on display, 2014]] The [[Pratt & Whitney F135]] powers the F-35. An alternative engine, the [[General Electric/Rolls-Royce F136]], was being developed until it was cancelled by its manufacturers in December 2011 for lack of funding from the Pentagon.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/06/11/327771/rolls-royce-f136-survival-is-key-for-major-f-35-engine.html "Rolls-Royce: F136 survival is key for major F-35 engine upgrade"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614073945/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/06/11/327771/rolls-royce-f136-survival-is-key-for-major-f-35-engine.html |date=14 June 2009 }} ''Flight International'', 11 June 2009.[https://archive.is/20120729014307/http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=8450963&c=AME&s=AIR "GE, Rolls Royce Stop Funding F-35 Alt Engine"]. ''Defense News'', 4 December 2011. The F135 and F136 engines are not designed to [[supercruise]].[http://www.jsf.mil/contact/con_faqs.htm "Frequently Asked Questions about JSF"]. ''JSF''. Retrieved 6 April 2010. However, the F-35 can briefly fly at Mach 1.2 for 150 miles without the use of an [[afterburner]].{{cite web|last=Tirpak|first=John|title=The F-35’s Race Against Time|url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2012/November%202012/1112fighter.aspx|publisher=[[Air Force Association]]|accessdate=4 November 2012|date=November 2012|quote=while not technically a "supercruising" aircraft, can maintain Mach 1.2 for a dash of 150 miles without using fuel-gulping afterburners|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121108143240/http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2012/November%202012/1112fighter.aspx |archivedate= 8 November 2012}} The F135 is the second (radar) stealthy afterburning jet engine. Like the [[Pratt & Whitney F119]] from which it was derived, the F135 has suffered afterburner pressure pulsations, or 'screech' at low altitude and high speed.Warwick, Graham. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPosto&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3a27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3a261f21c4-19ea-40e0-a756-ed0491972939&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "Screech, the F135 and the JSF Engine War"]. ''Aviation Week'', 17 March 2011. The F-35 has a maximum speed of over Mach 1.6. With a maximum takeoff weight of 60,000 lb (27,000 kg),{{efn|Quote: "The F-35A, with an air-to-air mission takeoff weight of 49,540 lb".}}{{cite web|url= http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/f35/f-35A-ctol-variant.html|title= F-35A Conventional Takeoff and Landing Variant|accessdate= 13 July 2012|last= [[Lockheed Martin]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317113904/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/f35/f-35A-ctol-variant.html |archivedate= 17 March 2011}} the Lightning II is considerably heavier than the lightweight fighters it replaces. [[File:Engine of F-35.jpg|thumb|left|The Pratt & Whitney F135 engine with [[Rolls-Royce LiftSystem]], including roll posts, and rear vectoring nozzle for the F-35B, at the 2007 [[Paris Air Show]]]] The STOVL F-35B is outfitted with the [[Rolls-Royce LiftSystem]], designed by Lockheed Martin and developed by Rolls-Royce. This system more resembles the German [[EWR VJ 101|VJ 101D/E]] than the preceding STOVL [[Harrier Jump Jet]] and the [[Rolls-Royce Pegasus]] engine."Swivel nozzle VJ101D and VJ101E". Vstol.org, 20 June 2009.Hirschberg, Mike. "[http://www.robertcmason.com/textdocs/GermanVSTOLFighters.pdf "V/STOL Fighter Programs in Germany: 1956–1975"], p. 50. International Powered Lift Conference, 1 November 2000. Retrieved 3 October 2012.[http://www.harrier.org.uk/technical/How_Hovers.htm "How the Harrier hovers"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707235558/http://www.harrier.org.uk/technical/How_Hovers.htm |date=7 July 2010 }}. ''harrier.org.'' Retrieved 16 November 2010. The Lift System is composed of a lift fan, drive shaft, two roll posts and a "Three Bearing Swivel Module" (3BSM).[http://www.rolls-royce.com/defence/products/combat_jets/rr_liftsystem.jsp "LiftSystem"]. ''Rolls-Royce''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. The 3BSM is a [[thrust vectoring]] [[vectoring nozzle|nozzle]] which allows the main engine exhaust to be deflected downward at the tail of the aircraft. The lift fan is near the front of the aircraft and provides a counterbalancing thrust using two counter-rotating [[blisk]]s.Zolfagharifard, Ellie. [http://www.theengineer.co.uk/in-depth/rolls-royces-liftsystem-for-the-joint-strike-fighter/1008008.article "Rolls-Royce's LiftSystem for the Joint Strike Fighter"] ''[[The Engineer (magazine)|The Engineer]]'', 28 March 2011. It is powered by the engine's low-pressure (LP) turbine via a drive shaft and gearbox. Roll control during slow flight is achieved by diverting unheated engine [[Bypass duct|bypass]] air through wing-mounted thrust nozzles called Roll Posts.Kjelgaard, Chris. [http://www.space.com/businesstechnology/071221-how-f-35b-stovl-propulsion-system-works.html "From Supersonic to Hover: How the F-35 Flies"]. ''Space'', 21 December 2007. Retrieved 18 October 2010.Hutchinson, John. [http://www.ingenia.org.uk/ingenia/issues/issue20/hutchinson.pdf "Going Vertical: Developing a STOVL system"]. ''ingenia.org.uk''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. F136 funding came at the expense of other program elements, impacting on unit costs.Warwick, Graham. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/SECOND052909.xml "Second Engine Could Cut F-35 Production"]. ''Aviation Week''. Retrieved 6 April 2010. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The F136 team stated their engine had a greater temperature margin, potentially critical for VTOL operations in hot, high altitude conditions."GE Rolls-Royce Fighter Engine Team completes study for Netherlands". ''rolls-royce.com''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Pratt & Whitney tested higher thrust versions of the F135, partly in response to GE's statements that the F136 is capable of producing more thrust than the {{convert|43000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}} of early F135s. In testing, the F135 has demonstrated a maximum thrust of over {{convert|50000|lbf|kN|abbr=on}};[https://web.archive.org/web/20101226060817/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=defense&id=news%2Fasd%2F2010%2F08%2F27%2F01.xml&headline=Pratt "Pratt Raises Stakes In JSF Engine Battle"]. ''Aviation Week'', 27 August 2010. Retrieved 25 November 2010. making it the most powerful engine ever installed in a fighter aircraft as of 2010."Lockheed Martin F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Succeeds In First Vertical Landing". ''lockheedmartin.com, Press Release,'' 18 March 2010. It is much heavier than previous fighter engines; the Heavy Underway Replenishment system needed to transfer the F135 between ships is an unfunded USN requirement.{{cite web|url=http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2013/pdf/navy/2013cvn78.pdf |title=FY 2013 Annual Report – CVN‑78 Gerald R. Ford Class Nuclear Aircraft Carrier |date=January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author=Director, Operational Test and Evaluation |others=Approved by: Director J. Michael Gilmore |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525041336/http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2013/pdf/navy/2013cvn78.pdf |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[Thermoelectric generator|Thermoelectric]]-powered sensors monitor turbine bearing health.Swedberg, Claire. [http://www.rfidjournal.com/article/articleview/8478/1/1/ "Energy-Harvesting Sensors to Monitor Health of Jet Engines"]. ''RFID Journal'', 31 May 2011. At the end of May 2017 Pratt and Whitney announced the F135 Growth Option 1 had finished testing and was available for production. The upgrade requires the changing of the power module on older engines and can be seamlessly inserted into future production engines at a minimal increase in unit cost and no impact to delivery schedule. The Growth Option 1 offers a improvement of 6–10% thrust across the F-35 flight envelope while also getting a 5–6% fuel burn reduction.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/pratt--whitney-validates-growth-option-for-f135-engine-300466212.html|title=Pratt & Whitney Validates Growth Option for F135 Engine|first=Pratt &|last=Whitney|website=www.prnewswire.com|accessdate=25 November 2017}} === Armament === [[File:F-35 weapons bay.jpeg|thumb|left|[[bomb bay|Weapons bay]] on an F-35 [[mock-up]]|alt=Close-up view of open aircraft weapons bay. The aircraft mock-up itself is on display, watched on by onlookers]] The F-35A is armed with a GAU-22/A, a four-barrel version of the [[25 mm caliber|25 mm]] [[GAU-12 Equalizer]] cannon.[http://www.gdatp.com/Products/Gun_Systems/Aircraft/F-35.asp "F-35 gun system"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606130602/http://www.gdatp.com/Products/Gun_Systems/Aircraft/F-35.asp |date=6 June 2011 }}, [http://www.gdatp.com/files/PDF/A118_GAU22.pdf "GAU-22/A"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717135842/http://www.gdatp.com/files/PDF/A118_GAU22.pdf |date=17 July 2011 }}. General Dynamics Armament and Technical Products. Retrieved 7 April 2011. The cannon is mounted internally with 182 rounds for the F-35A or in an external pod with 220 rounds for the F-35B and F-35C;[http://www.jsf.mil/downloads/mediakits/7764.zip "F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Media Kit Statistics"]. JSF.mil August 2004.Keijsper 2007, p. 233. the gun pod has stealth features. Software updates to enable operational firing of the cannon are expected to be completed by 2018.{{cite web|title=software issue|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-f-35-wont-fire-a-shot-until-2019-2014-12?IR=T}} The F-35 has two internal [[bomb bay|weapons bays]], and external [[hardpoint]]s for mounting up to four underwing pylons and two near wingtip pylons. The two outer hardpoints can carry pylons for the [[AIM-9X]] Sidewinder and AIM-132 [[ASRAAM]] short-range [[air-to-air missile]]s (AAM) only.Hewson, Robert. [http://www.janes.com/products/janes/defence-security-report.aspx?ID=1065928225 "UK changes JSF configuration for ASRAAM"]. ''Jane's'', 4 March 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916123905/http://www.janes.com/products/janes/defence-security-report.aspx?ID=1065928225 |date=16 September 2012 }} The other pylons can carry the [[AIM-120 AMRAAM]] [[Beyond-visual-range missile|BVR]] AAM, [[AGM-158 JASSM|AGM-158 Joint Air to Surface Stand-off Missile]] (JASSM) cruise missile, and [[guided bomb]]s. The external pylons can carry missiles, bombs, and [[external fuel tank]]s at the expense of increased [[radar cross-section]], and thus reduced stealth.Keijsper 2007, pp. 220, 239. There are a total of four weapons stations between the two internal bays. Two of these can carry [[air-to-surface missile]]s or bombs up to {{convert|2000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} each in the A and C models, or air-to-surface missiles or bombs up to {{convert|1000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} each in the B model; the other two stations are for smaller weapons such as air-to-air missiles.Davis, Brigadier General Charles R. [http://www.jsf.mil/downloads/documents/AFA_Conf_-_JSF_Program_Brief_-_26_Sept_06.pdf "F-35 Program Brief"]. ''USAF'', 26 September 2006.[http://es.is.itt.com/JSF%20Suite.htm "JSF Suite: BRU-67, BRU-68, LAU-147 – Carriage Systems: Pneumatic Actuated, Single Carriage"].{{dead link|date=November 2013}} es.is.itt.com, 2009. The weapon bays can carry AIM-120 AMRAAM, [[AIM-132 ASRAAM]], the [[Joint Direct Attack Munition]] (JDAM), [[Paveway]] series of bombs, the [[AGM-154 Joint Standoff Weapon|Joint Standoff Weapon]] (JSOW), [[Brimstone (missile)|Brimstone]] [[anti-tank missile]]s, and [[cluster munition]]s ([[Wind Corrected Munitions Dispenser]]). An air-to-air missile load of eight AIM-120s and two AIM-9s is possible using internal and external weapons stations; a configuration of six {{convert|2000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} bombs, two AIM-120s and two AIM-9s can also be arranged.Digger, Davis. [http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2007targets/Day1/Davisday1.pdf "JSF Range & Airspace Requirements"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219205327/http://www.dtic.mil/ndia/2007targets/Day1/Davisday1.pdf |date=19 December 2008 }}. ''Headquarters Air Combat Command'', Defense Technical Information Center, 30 October 2007. The [[Terma A/S]] multi-mission pod (MMP) could be used for different equipment and purposes, such as [[electronic warfare]], [[aerial reconnaissance]], or rear-facing tactical radar.Donald, David. [http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/defense/2012-07-11/terma-highlights-f-35-multi-mission-pod "Terma Highlights F-35 Multi-Mission Pod"]. ''AINonline'', 11 July 2012. The British Ministry of Defence plan to fire the [[SPEAR 3|Select Precision Effects at Range (SPEAR) Capability 3]] missile from the internal bays of the F-35B, with four missiles per bay.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/411-million-investment-in-new-missile-for-uks-new-jets-sustains-700-uk-jobs/ |title=£411 million investment in new missile for UK's new jets sustains 700 UK jobs |date=18 March 2016 |publisher=UK Ministry of Defence}}{{cite web |url=http://www.janes360.com/images/assets/853/47853/the_UK_s_SPEAR_Cap_3_air-to-surface_weapon.pdf |title=Aimpoint selection: the UK's SPEAR Cap 3 air-to surface weapon |date=18 March 2016 |publisher=IHS}} Lockheed Martin states that the weapons load can be configured as all-air-to-ground or all-air-to-air, and has suggested that a Block 5 version will carry three weapons per bay instead of two, replacing the heavy bomb with two smaller weapons such as AIM-120 AMRAAM air-to-air missiles.Lake 2010, pp. 37–45. Upgrades are to allow each weapons bay to carry four [[Small Diameter Bomb|GBU-39 Small Diameter Bombs]] (SDB) for A and C models, or three in F-35B.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090223163759/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/f35/f-35-variants/f-35b-stovl-variant.html "F-35B STOVL Variant"]. Lockheed Martin. Retrieved 25 November 2010. Another option is four [[GBU-53/B]] Small Diameter Bomb IIs in each bay on all F-35 variants.[http://www.defense-update.com/products/s/sdb_2_25082010.html "Small Diameter Bomb II – GBU-53/B"]. ''Defense Update''. Retrieved 28 August 2010. The F-35A has been outfitted with four SDB II bombs and an AMRAAM missile to test adequate bay door clearance,{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/raytheon-us-air-force-complete-small-diameter-bomb-ii-fit-check-on-f-35-aircraft-2013-01-22 |title=Raytheon, US Air Force complete Small Diameter Bomb II fit check on F-35 aircraft |work=marketwatch.com |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219021537/http://www.marketwatch.com/story/raytheon-us-air-force-complete-small-diameter-bomb-ii-fit-check-on-f-35-aircraft-2013-01-22 |archivedate=19 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |author1=The U.S. Air Force |author2=Raytheon Company |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=PRNewswire}} as well as the C-model, but the STOVL F-35B will not be able to carry the required load of four SDB IIs in each weapons bay upon reaching IOC because of weight and dimension constraints; F-35B bay changes are to be incorporated to increase SDB II loadout around 2022 in line with the Block 4 weapons suite.[http://insidedefense.com/share/167668 F-35B Internal Weapons Bay Can't Fit Required Load Of Small Diameter Bomb IIs] – Insidedefense.com, 25 February 2015 The [[Meteor (missile)|Meteor]] air-to-air missile may be adapted for the F-35, a modified Meteor with smaller tailfins for the F-35 was revealed in September 2010; plans call for the carriage of four Meteors internally.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/09/17/347416/picture-mbda-reveals-clipped-fin-meteor-for-f-35.html "MBDA reveals clipped-fin Meteor for F-35"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921000829/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/09/17/347416/picture-mbda-reveals-clipped-fin-meteor-for-f-35.html |date=21 September 2010 }} ''Flight International'', 7 November 2010. The United Kingdom planned to use up to four AIM-132 ASRAAM missiles internally, later plans call for the carriage of two internal and two external ASRAAMs.[http://www.f-16.net/news_article2762.html "F-35 Lightning II News: ASRAAM Config Change For F-35"]. f-16.net, 4 March 2008. The external ASRAAMs are planned to be carried on "stealthy" pylons; the missile allows attacks to slightly beyond visual range without employing radar.Tran, Pierre. "MBDA Shows Off ASRAAM". ''Defense News'', 22 February 2008. Norway and Australia are funding an adaptation of the [[Naval Strike Missile]] (NSM) for the F-35. Under the designation [[Joint Strike Missile]] (JSM), it is to be the only cruise missile to fit the F-35's internal bays; according to studies two JSMs can be carried internally with an additional four externally.[http://www.kongsberg.com/en/KOG/News/2009/June/0906JSMAndLockheedMartin.aspx "Important cooperative agreement with Lockheed Martin"]. ''Kongsberg Defence & Aerospace'', 9 June 2009. The F-35 is expected to take on the [[Wild Weasel]] mission, though there are no planned [[anti-radiation missile]]s for internal carriage.Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/11/04/349306/raytheon-gets-darpa-boost-for-amraam-harm-replacement.html "Raytheon gets DARPA boost for AMRAAM, HARM replacement"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101108145333/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/11/04/349306/raytheon-gets-darpa-boost-for-amraam-harm-replacement.html |date=8 November 2010 }} ''Flight International'', 4 November 2010. In September 2016, Orbital ATK unveiled its extended-range AARGM-ER incorporating a redesigned control section and 11.5 in (290 mm)-diameter rocket motor for twice the range for internal carriage on the F-35.{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} The [[B61 nuclear bomb]] was initially scheduled for deployment in 2017;Reed, John. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/04/06/minuteman-iii-follow-on-being-eyed-nukes-for-jsf-delayed/ "Minuteman III Follow-On Being Eyed, Nukes for JSF Delayed"]. ''DoD Buzz'', 6 April 2011. as of 2012 it was expected to be in the early 2020s,Muradian, Vego. [https://web.archive.org/web/20121015151001/http://www.defensenewstv.com/video.php?bctid=1897052351001 "The Future of the U.S. Nuclear Enterprise"]. ''Defense News'', 14 October 2012. and in 2014 Congress moved to cut funding for the needed weapons integration work.{{cite web |url=http://www.nti.org/gsn/article/nuclear-security-and-omnibus-legislation-whats-and-whats-down/ |title=Nuclear Security and Omnibus Legislation: What's Up and What's Down |last1=Guarino |first1=Douglas P. |date=16 January 2014 |website= nti.org |publisher=Global Security Newswire |accessdate=16 January 2014}} [[Norton A. Schwartz]] agreed with the move and said that "F-35 investment dollars should realign to the [[Next-Generation Bomber|long-range strike bomber]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.militarytimes.com/article/20140117/NEWS04/301170014 |title=Schwartz: Move away from nuclear F-35 |last1=Mehta |first1=Aaron |date=17 January 2014 |website=militarytimes.com |publisher=Gannett Government Media |accessdate=17 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203014928/https://www.militarytimes.com/article/20140117/NEWS04/301170014 |archivedate=3 February 2014 |df=dmy }} NATO partners who are buying the F-35 but cannot afford to make them dual-capable want the USAF to fund the conversions to allow their Lightning IIs to carry [[thermonuclear weapon]]s. The USAF is trying to convince NATO partners who can afford the conversions to contribute to funding for those that cannot. The F-35 Block 4B will be able to carry two [[B61 nuclear bomb]]s internally by 2024.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforcemag.com/DRArchive/Pages/2014/March%202014/March%2017%202014/Nuclear-Lightning.aspx |title=Nuclear Lightning |work=airforcemag.com |date=17 March 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=John A. |last=Tirpak |publisher=Air Force Association |location=Arlington, VA |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525022806/http://www.airforcemag.com/DRArchive/Pages/2014/March%202014/March%2017%202014/Nuclear-Lightning.aspx |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} According to reports in 2002, [[solid-state laser]]s were being developed as optional weapons for the F-35.Fulghum, David A. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040626050316/http://www.aviationnow.com/content/publication/awst/20020708/aw32.htm "Lasers being developed for F-35 and AC-130"]. ''Aviation Week and Space Technology'', 8 July 2002.Morris, Jefferson. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040604124353/http://www.aviationnow.com/avnow/news/channel_military.jsp?view=story&id=news%2Fmasd0926.xml "Keeping cool a big challenge for JSF laser, Lockheed Martin says"]. ''Aerospace Daily'', 26 September 2002.Fulghum, David A. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040613094437/http://www.aviationnow.com/content/publication/awst/20020722/aw173.htm "Lasers, HPM weapons near operational status"]. ''Aviation Week and Space Technology'', 22 July 2002. Lockheed is studying integrating a [[fiber laser]] onto the aircraft that uses spectral beam combining to channel energy from a stack of individual laser modules into a single, high-power beam, which can be scaled up or down for various levels of effects. Adding a laser would give the F-35 the ability to essentially burn missiles and other aircraft out of the sky.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-considering-laser-weapon-concepts-for-f-35-417416/ Lockheed considering laser weapon concepts for F-35] – Flightglobal.com, 5 October 2015 The F-35 is also one of the target platforms for the [[Boeing X-51|High Speed Strike Weapon]] if hypersonic missile development is successful.{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_05_20_2013_p24-579062.xml |title=High-Speed Strike Weapon To Build On X-51 Flight |last1=Norris |first1=Guy |date=20 May 2013 |work=www.aviationweek.com |publisher=Aviation Week |accessdate=26 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520230214/https://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=%2Farticle-xml%2FAW_05_20_2013_p24-579062.xml |archivedate=20 May 2013 |df=dmy }} The Air Force plans to use the F-35A to primarily take up the [[close air support]] (CAS) mission in contested environments. Amid criticism that the aircraft is not well suited for the role compared to a dedicated attack platform, Air Force chief of staff [[Mark Welsh]] is putting focus on weapons for the F-35 to employ on CAS sorties including [[Hydra 70#Precision guided Hydra 70|guided rockets]], fragmentation rockets that would shatter into individual projectiles before impact, and lighter, smaller ammunition in higher capacity gun pods.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-chief-keeps-sights-on-close-air-support-mission-409070/ USAF chief keeps sights on close air support mission] – Flightglobal.com, 15 February 2015 Fragmentary rocket warheads would have greater effects than cannon shells fired from a gun because a single rocket would create a "thousand-round burst", delivering more projectiles than a strafing run could. Other weapons could take advantage of the aircraft's helmet-mounted cueing system to aim rather than needing to point the nose at a target.[http://aviationweek.com/defense/long-road-ahead-possible-10-follow Long Road Ahead For Possible A-10 Follow-On] – Aviationweek.com, 24 March 2015 [[Institute for the Study of War]]'s Christopher Harmer has questioned the use of such an expensive aircraft for CAS.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/04/09/politics/a-10-warthog-replacement/ |title=Air Force looking to replace A-10 Warthog |last1=Browne |first1=Ryan |date=9 April 2016 |website=www.cnn.com |publisher=CNN |accessdate=9 April 2016}} === Stealth and signatures === ==== Radar ==== [[File:JSF F35 P1230144.jpg|thumb|Landing gear door of the F-35 mockup, showing its stealth sawtooth design]] The F-35 has been designed to have a low [[radar cross-section]] that is primarily due to the shape of the aircraft and the use of [[Stealth technology|stealthy]], [[radar-absorbent material]]s in its construction, including fiber-mat.Butler, Amy. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/asd/2010/05/17/10.xml&headline=New%20Stealth%20Concept%20Could%20Affect%20JSF%20Cost "New Stealth Concept Could Affect JSF Cost"]. ''Aviation Week'', 17 May 2010. Retrieved 5 June 2010. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Unlike the previous generation of fighters, the F-35 was designed for very-low-observable characteristics.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35-design.htm "F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Lightning II"]. GlobalSecurity.org. Retrieved 16 November 2010. Besides radar stealth measures, the F-35 incorporates [[infrared signature]] and [[aircraft camouflage|visual signature]] reduction measures.[http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2000/airforce/00jsf.html "USAF FY00 activity on the JSF"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723171357/http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2000/airforce/00jsf.html |date=23 July 2011 }} ''U.S. Director, Operational Test & Evaluation.'' Retrieved: 17 l 2012.[http://www.regjeringen.no/upload/FD/Temadokumenter/JSF_RBI-svar.pdf "F-35 Norwegian Executive Summary"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012064324/http://www.regjeringen.no/upload/FD/Temadokumenter/JSF_RBI-svar.pdf |date=12 October 2012 }} Lockheed Martin, April 2008. The Fighter [[Teen Series]] (F-14, F-15, F-16, F/A-18) carried large external fuel tanks, but to avoid negating its stealth characteristics the F-35 must fly most missions without them. Unlike the F-16 and F/A-18, the F-35 lacks [[leading edge extension]]s and instead uses stealth-friendly [[Chine (aeronautics)|chines]] for vortex lift in the same fashion as the [[SR-71 Blackbird]].Bolsøy, Bjørnar. [http://www.f-16.net/news_article3837.html "F-35 Lightning II status and future prospects"]. f-16.net, 17 September 2009. Retrieved 23 November 2009. The small bumps just forward of the engine air intakes form part of the [[diverterless supersonic inlet]] (DSI) which is a simpler, lighter means to ensure high-quality airflow to the engine over a wide range of conditions. These inlets also crucially improve the aircraft's very-low-observable characteristics (by eliminating radar reflections between the diverter and the aircraft's skin).Hehs, Eric. [http://www.codeonemagazine.com/article.html?item_id=58 "JSF Diverterless Supersonic Inlet"]. ''Code One Magazine''. Retrieved 28 December 2012. Additionally, the "bump" surface reduces the engine's exposure to radar, significantly reducing a strong source of radar reflection[http://aviationintel.com/2012/10/22/fast-history-lockheeds-diverterless-supersonic-inlet-testbed-f-16/ "Fast History: Lockheed's Diverterless Supersonic Inlet Testbed F-16"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907000042/http://aviationintel.com/2012/10/22/fast-history-lockheeds-diverterless-supersonic-inlet-testbed-f-16/ |date=7 September 2013 }} ''aviationintel.com'', 13 January 2013 because they provide an additional shielding of engine fans against radar waves. The Y-duct type air [[intake ramp]]s also help in reducing radar cross-section (RCS), because the intakes run parallel and not directly into the engine fans. [[File:A U.S. Air Force pilot navigates an F-35A Lightning II aircraft assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron, 33rd Fighter Wing into position to refuel with a KC-135 Stratotanker assigned to the 336th Air Refueling 130516-F-XL333-404.jpg|thumb|left|F-35A front profile in flight. The doors are opened to expose the [[aerial refueling]] inlet valve.]] The F-35's radar-absorbent materials are designed to be more durable and less maintenance-intensive than those of its predecessors. At optimal frequencies, the F-35 compares favorably to the F-22 in stealth, according to General [[Gilmary M. Hostage III|Mike Hostage]], Commander of the [[Air Combat Command]].{{cite web|url=http://breakingdefense.com/2015/03/threat-data-biggest-worry-for-f-35as-ioc-but-it-will-be-on-time/|title=Threat Data Biggest Worry For F-35A’s IOC; But It ‘Will Be On Time’|work=Breaking Defense|accessdate=31 March 2015}}Clark, Colin. [http://breakingdefense.com/2014/06/gen-mike-hostage-on-the-f-35-no-growlers-needed-when-war-starts/3/] ''Breaking Defense'', 6 June 2014. Like other stealth fighters, however, the F-35 is more susceptible to detection by [[low-frequency radar]]s because of the [[Rayleigh scattering]] resulting from the aircraft's physical size. However, such radars are also conspicuous, susceptible to clutter, and have low precision.Ralston, J; Heagy, J; et al. [http://www.dtic.mil/dtic/tr/fulltext/u2/a359931.pdf "Environmental/Noise Effects on UHF/VHF UWB SAR".] ''dtic.mil'', September 1998. Retrieved: 2 January 2015.Plopsky, Guy and Fabrizio Bozzato. [http://thediplomat.com/2014/08/the-f-35-vs-the-vhf-threat/ "The F-35 vs. The VHF Threat"]. ''The Diplomat'', 21 August 2014. Although fighter-sized stealth aircraft could be detected by low-frequency radar, missile lock and targeting sensors primarily operate in the [[X-band radar|X-band]], which F-35 RCS reduction is made for, so they cannot engage unless at close range.[http://defense-update.com/20150614_f35_beyond_stealth.html#.VYisUsIw8dU F-35 – Beyond Stealth] – Defense-Update.com, 14 June 2015 Because the aircraft's shape is important to the RCS, special care must be taken to match the "[[Boilerplate (spaceflight)|boilerplate]]" during production.Capaccio, Tony. [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-05-04/lockheed-martin-s-f-35-fighter-jet-passes-initial-stealth-hurdle.html "Lockheed Martin’s F-35 Fighter Jet Passes Initial Stealth Hurdle"]. ''Bloomberg News'', 4 May 2011. Ground crews require Repair Verification Radar (RVR) test sets to verify the RCS after performing repairs, which is not a concern for non-stealth aircraft.{{cite web |url=http://www.defenseworld.net/news/5268/Lockheed_Martin_wins__13_million_contract_for_Strike_Fighter_aircraft_from_US_Air_Force#.VKuy_HuxXP4 |title=Lockheed Martin wins $13 million contract for Strike Fighter aircraft from US Air Force|work=defenseworld.net |date=22 November 2010 |accessdate=6 January 2014}}Brewer, Jeffrey and Shawn Meadows. [http://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?Location=U2&doc=GetTRDoc.pdf&AD=ADA529057 "Survivability of the Next Strike Fighter", p. 23.] ''Aircraft Survivability: Susceptibility Reduction'' via ''Joint Aircraft Survivability Program Office (JASPO)'', Summer 2006. ==== Acoustics ==== In 2008, the Air Force revealed that the F-35 would be about twice as loud as the [[McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle]] at takeoff and up to four times as loud during landing.Alaimo, Carol Ann. [http://azstarnet.com/news/local/article_b8e6b612-1751-5554-8819-166f110f0f24.html "Noisy F-35 Still Without A Home"]. ''[[Arizona Daily Star]]'', 30 November 2008. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Residents near [[Luke Air Force Base]], Arizona, and [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida, possible F-35 bases, requested environmental impact studies be conducted regarding the F-35's noise levels. In 2009, the city of [[Valparaiso, Florida|Valparaiso]], Florida, adjacent to Eglin AFB, threatened to sue over the impending F-35 arrival; this lawsuit was settled in March 2010.Moore, Mona. "Val-P to sue the Air Force". ''Northwest Florida Daily News'', 19 February 2009, Volume 63, Number 20, p. A1.Barlow, Kari C. [http://www.thedestinlog.com/news/legal-28112-nwfdn-fees-okaloosa.html "Val-p wants Okaloosa to reimburse F-35 legal fees"]. thedestinlog.com, 16 April 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405042733/http://www.thedestinlog.com/news/legal-28112-nwfdn-fees-okaloosa.html |date=5 April 2012 }}Nicholson, Brendan. [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/noise-triggers-legal-bid-to-down-jet-fighter/story-fn59niix-1226037459254 "Noise triggers legal bid to down jet fighter"]. ''The Australian'', 12 April 2011. In 2009, testing reportedly revealed the F-35 to be: "only about as noisy as an [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16]] fitted with a Pratt & Whitney F100-PW-200 engine ... quieter than the Lockheed Martin F-22 Raptor and the Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet".Perrett, Bradley. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/F35-031209.xml "F-35 May Need Thermal Management Changes"]. ''Aviation Week'', 12 March 2009. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} An acoustics study by Lockheed Martin and the Air Force found F-35's noise levels to be comparable to the F-22 and F/A-18E/F.[https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:0yIuRIMUDwcJ:www.f-16.net/f-16_forum_download-id-11481.html+F-35+acoustics+test&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgfOwRZ9Cjk22IknVc6me97wPUsleYuw0aMTdia4Djkgx1C9hhiMOuSU_O7s1I8aaIh_NhSvO0kZlrK_05iNQvB_iCtyQWQ7d4uPEYz4oCoC6efEnxiqD1xkpsZ952kVNoAxgyE&sig=AHIEtbTRsgZXOeGUg90opGYn6e-msBU02w "Joint Communications Release, JSF Program Office & Lockheed Martin. Subject: F-35 Acoustics Based on Edwards AFB Acoustics, Test"]. ''JSF Program Office & Lockheed Martin,'' April 2009. Retrieved 15 January 2011. A USAF environmental impact study found that replacing F-16s with F-35s at [[Tucson International Airport]] would subject more than 21 times as many residents to extreme noise levels.Alaimo, Carol Ann. [http://azstarnet.com/news/local/noisy-f--could-affect-thousands-in-tucson-study-finds/article_38ad2ab4-c151-5ee4-ae7c-9bc81c537a54.html "Noisy F-35 could affect thousands, study finds"]. ''Arizona Daily Star'', 13 June 2012. The USN will need to redesign hearing protection for sailors to protect against the "thundering 152 decibels" of the F-35.{{cite web |url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140409/DEFREG02/304090026 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140409131749/http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140409/DEFREG02/304090026 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=9 April 2014 |title=F-35 Forcing Navy To Develop New Hearing Protection For Flight Deck Crews |last1=MYERS |first1=MEGHANN |date=9 April 2014 |website= defensenews.com |publisher=Gannett Government Media |accessdate=9 April 2014}} The Joint Strike Fighter program office found in October 2014 that the F-35B's take-off noise was only two decibels higher than a Super Hornet, a virtually indistinguishable difference to the human ear, and is even 10 decibels quieter when flying formations or landing.[http://defensetech.org/2014/11/25/f-35bs-no-louder-than-fa-18-super-hornets/ F-35Bs No Louder than F/A-18 Super Hornets] – Defensetech.org, 25 November 2014 === Cockpit === [[File:Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II mock-up instrument panel.JPG|thumb|F-35 cockpit mock-up]] The F-35 features a full-panel-width [[glass cockpit]] [[touchscreen]]{{cite web|url=http://wordlesstech.com/2012/07/19/lockheed-martins-f-35-lightning-ii-most-advanced-cockpit/|title="Lockheed Martin’s F-35 Lightning II most advanced cockpit" at wordlesstech.com|work=wordlessTech}} "panoramic cockpit display" (PCD), with dimensions of 20 by 8 inches (50 by 20 centimeters).Goebel, Greg. [http://www.vectorsite.net/avf35.html "The Lockheed Martin F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF)"]. vectorsite.net. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622162234/http://www.vectorsite.net/avf35.html |date=22 June 2012 }} A [[Direct Voice Input|cockpit speech-recognition system]] (DVI) provided by [[Adacel]] has been adopted on the F-35 and the aircraft will be the first operational U.S. fixed-wing aircraft to employ this DVI system, although similar systems have been used on the [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B Harrier II]] and trialed in previous aircraft, such as the [[General Dynamics F-16 VISTA|F-16 VISTA]].Schutte, John. [http://www.afmc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123071564 "Researchers fine-tune F-35 pilot-aircraft speech system"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423232632/http://www.afmc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123071564 |date=23 April 2016 }} ''US Air Force'', 10 October 2007. A [[helmet-mounted display]] system (HMDS) will be fitted to all models of the F-35."Joint Helmet Mounted Cueing System". Boeing. Retrieved 23 November 2009. While some fighters have offered HMDS along with a [[head up display]] (HUD), this will be the first time in several decades that a front line fighter has been designed without a HUD.[http://www.rockwellcollins.com/news/page8813.html "VSI's Helmet Mounted Display System flies on Joint Strike Fighter"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817153107/http://www.rockwellcollins.com/news/page8813.html |date=17 August 2011 }} ''Rockwell Collins'', 2007. Retrieved 8 June 2008. The F-35 is equipped with a right-hand [[HOTAS]] [[side-stick|side stick]] controller. The [[Martin-Baker]] US16E [[ejection seat]] is used in all F-35 variants.[http://www.jsf.org.uk/JSF-UK-Industry-Team/Martin-Baker.aspx "Martin-Baker"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021165256/http://www.jsf.org.uk/JSF-UK-Industry-Team/Martin-Baker.aspx |date=21 October 2008 }} ''JSF''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. The US16E seat design balances major performance requirements, including safe-terrain-clearance limits, pilot-load limits, and pilot size; it uses a twin-catapult system housed in side rails."JSF" ''Martin-Baker''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. This industry standard ejection seat can cause the heavier than usual helmet to inflict serious injury on lightweight pilots.{{cite news |url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/breaking-news/2015/10/14/f-35s-heavier-helmet-complicates-ejection-risks/73922710/ |title=F-35's Heavier Helmet Complicates Ejection Risks |last1=Seligman |first1=Lara |date=14 October 2015 |website=www.defensenews.com |publisher=TEGNA |accessdate=15 October 2015}} The F-35 employs an oxygen system derived from the F-22's own system, which has been involved in multiple [[Hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]] incidents on that aircraft; unlike the F-22, the flight profile of the F-35 is similar to other fighters that routinely use such systems.Peladeau, Jean. [http://www.lfpress.com/news/canada/2012/05/11/19748046.html "Pilots worry about F-35 oxygen system"]. ''QMI Agency'', 11 May 2012.Bennett, John T. [https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/dotmil/2012/05/24/f-22s-oxygen-issues-raise-questions-about-f-35 "F-22's Oxygen Issues Raise Questions About F-35"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525051539/http://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/dotmil/2012/05/24/f-22s-oxygen-issues-raise-questions-about-f-35 |date=25 May 2012 }} ''US News'', 24 May 2012. On June 9, 2017, the 55 F-35s at [[Luke Air Force Base]] were grounded after five pilots complained of hypoxia-like symptoms over a five-week span. Symptoms ranged from dizziness to tingling in their extremities. The suspension was initially expected to last one day, but was extended to give investigators more time. Flying was resumed on 20 June, with no direct cause having been found.{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/glendale/2017/06/20/f-35-flight-suspension-luke-afb-ends-cause-hypoxia-not-found/410946001/|title=F-35 flight suspension at Luke AFB ends; cause of hypoxia not found|publisher=|accessdate=21 June 2017}} === Sensors and avionics === [[File:F-35 EOTS.jpeg|thumb|left|Electro-optical target system (EOTS) under the nose of a mockup of the F-35]] The F-35's sensor and communications suite has [[situational awareness]], [[command and control]] and [[network-centric warfare]] capabilities.{{cite interview |first=Eric |subject=George |interviewer= |title=F-35 avionics: an interview with the Joint Strike Fighter's director of mission systems and software |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-21/issue-5/news/news/f-35-avionics__an.html |date=1 May 2010 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |volume=21 |issue=5 |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The main sensor on board is the [[APG-81|AN/APG-81]] [[active electronically scanned array]]-radar, designed by [[Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems]].[http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35aesaradar/ "APG-81 (F-35 Lightning II)"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123033148/http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35aesaradar/ |date=23 January 2013 }} Northrop Grumman Electronic Systems. Retrieved 4 August 2007. It is augmented by the nose-mounted Electro-Optical Targeting System (EOTS),[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/JointStrikeFighterElectroOpticalTar/ "Lockheed Martin Missiles and Fire Control: Joint Strike Fighter Electro-Optical Targeting System"]. Lockheed Martin. Retrieved 11 April 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106235314/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/JointStrikeFighterElectroOpticalTar/ |date=6 January 2009 }} it provides the capabilities of an externally mounted [[Sniper Advanced Targeting Pod]] with a reduced [[radar cross-section]].Scott, William B. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/10044top.xml "Sniper Targeting Pod Attacks From Long Standoff Ranges"]. ''Aviation Week'', 3 October 2004. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415042219/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_generic.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/10044top.xml |date=15 April 2012 }}Pappalardo, Joe. [http://www.origin.popularmechanics.com/technology/military_law/4339113.html "How an F-35 Targets, Aims and Fires Without Being Seen"].{{dead link|date=November 2013}} ''Popular Mechanics'', December 2009. Retrieved: 6 April 2010. The AN/ASQ-239 (Barracuda) system is an improved version of the F-22's [[AN/ALR-94]] electronic warfare suite, providing [[sensor fusion]] of [[radio frequency]] and infrared tracking functions, advanced [[radar warning receiver]] including geolocation targeting of threats, [[multispectral image]] countermeasures for self-defense against missiles, [[situational awareness]] and [[electronic surveillance]], employing 10 [[radio frequency]] antennae embedded into the edges of the wing and tail.{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/19/Electronic-Warfare-Australias-mixed-record |title=Electronic Warfare: Australia's mixed record | Australian Defence News & Articles |publisher=Asia Pacific Defence Reporter |accessdate=24 February 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/217/Electronic-Warfare |title=Electronic Warfare | Australian Defence News & Articles |publisher=Asia Pacific Defence Reporter |accessdate=24 February 2013}} In September 2015, Lockheed unveiled the "Advanced EOTS" that offers short-wave infrared, high-definition television, infrared marker, and superior image detector resolution capabilities. Offered for the Block 4 configuration, it fits into the same area as the baseline EOTS with minimal changes while preserving stealth features.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lockheed-reveals-advanced-eots-targeting-sensor-for-416631/ Lockheed reveals Advanced EOTS targeting sensor for F-35 Block 4] – Flightglobal.com, 10 September 2015 Six additional [[Thermographic camera|passive infrared sensors]] are distributed over the aircraft as part of [[Northrop Grumman]]'s electro-optical [[AN/AAQ-37]] Distributed Aperture System (DAS),[http://www.es.northropgrumman.com/solutions/f35targeting/ "F-35 Distributed Aperture System (EO DAS)"]. ''Northrop Grumman''. Retrieved 6 April 2010. which acts as a [[Missile Approach Warning|missile warning system]], reports missile launch locations, detects and tracks approaching aircraft spherically around the F-35, and replaces traditional [[night vision device]]s. All DAS functions are performed simultaneously, [[All-aspect|in every direction]], at all times. The [[electronic warfare]] systems are designed by [[BAE Systems]] and include Northrop Grumman components.[http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewnewspaged/articleid/3442641/pageid/2 "JSF EW Suite"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918011209/http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewnewspaged/articleid/3442641/pageid/2 |date=18 September 2010 }} istockanalyst.com. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Functions such as the Electro-Optical Targeting System and the electronic warfare system are not usually integrated on fighters.{{cite web|last=Tirpak |first=John A |title=Slow Climb for the F-35 |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2012/October%202012/1012slow.pdf |publisher=AIR FORCE Magazine |accessdate=3 October 2012 |page=42 |date=October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120161246/https://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2012/October%202012/1012slow.pdf |archivedate=20 November 2012 |df=dmy }} The F-35's DAS is so sensitive, it reportedly detected the launch of an air-to-air missile in a training exercise from {{convert|1,200|mi|km|abbr=on}} away, which in combat would give away the location of an enemy aircraft even if it had a very low [[radar cross-section]].[http://breakingdefense.com/2014/06/a-gods-eye-view-of-the-battlefield-gen-hostage-on-the-f-35/4/ ‘A God’s Eye View Of The Battlefield:’ Gen. Hostage On The F-35] – Breakingdefense.com, 6 June 2014 [[File:AN-APG-81 Antenna, 2005 - National Electronics Museum - DSC00393.JPG|thumb|[[APG-81|AN/APG-81]] [[Active electronically scanned array|AESA]]-radar]] The communications, navigation and identification (CNI) suite is designed by Northrop Grumman and includes the [[Multifunction Advanced Data Link]] (MADL), as one of a half dozen different physical links.{{cite web |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-14/issue-5/features/special-report/f-35-jet-fighters-to-take-integrated-avionics-to-a-whole-new-level.html |title=F-35 jet fighters to take integrated avionics to a whole new level |date=1 May 2003 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The F-35 will be the first fighter with [[sensor fusion]] that combines radio frequency and IR tracking for continuous all-direction target detection and identification which is shared via MADL to other platforms [[Encryption|without compromising low observability]].Nativi, Andy. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/F35-030509.xml "F-35 Air Combat Skills Analyzed"]. ''Aviation Week'', 5 March 2009. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101226061121/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news%2FF35-030509.xml |date=26 December 2010 }} [[Link 16]] is also included for communication with legacy systems.[http://defense-update.com/20120727_israel-us-negotiate-450-million-f-35i-avionic-enhancements.html "Israel, US Negotiate $450 Million F-35I Avionic Enhancements"]. ''Defense Update'', 27 July 2012. The F-35 has been designed with synergy between sensors as a specific requirement, the aircraft's "senses" being expected to provide a more cohesive picture of the [[battlespace]] around it and be available for use in any possible way and combination with one another; for example, the AN/APG-81 multi-mode radar also acts as a part of the electronic warfare system.Sherman, Ron. [http://www.aviationtoday.com/av/categories/military/845.html "F-35 Electronic Warfare Suite: More Than Self-Protection"]. aviationtoday.com, 1 July 2006. Retrieved 22 August 2010. The Program Executive Officer (PEO) General [[Christopher Bogdan|Bogdan]] has described the sensor fusion software as one of the most difficult parts of the program.{{cite web |url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473499/program-executive-officer-describes-f-35-progress.aspx |title=Program executive officer describes F-35 progress |last1=Lyle |first1=Amaani |date=6 March 2014 |website= af.mil |publisher=American Forces Press Service |accessdate=6 March 2014}} Much of the F-35's software is written in C and [[C++]] because of programmer availability; [[Ada (programming language)|Ada83]] code also is reused from the F-22.{{cite web|url=https://journal.thecsiac.com/issue/53/158 |title=Hey C and C++ Can Be Used In Safety Critical Applications Too! |work=Journal.thecsiac.com |date=11 February 2001 |accessdate=24 February 2013}} The [[INTEGRITY-178B|Integrity DO-178B]] real-time operating system (RTOS) from [[Green Hills Software]] runs on [[Commercial off-the-shelf|COTS]] Freescale PowerPC processors.{{cite web |last=McHale |first=John |url=http://www.militaryaerospace.com/articles/print/volume-21/issue-2/news/news/f-35-joint-strike-fighter-leverages-cots-for-avionics-systems.html |title=F-35 Joint Strike Fighter leverages COTS for avionics systems|date=1 February 2010 |work=Military & Aerospace Electronics |publisher=PennWell Corporation |accessdate=27 November 2014}} The final Block 3 software is planned to have 8.6 million lines of code.Warwick, Graham. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/awst/2010/06/07/AW_06_07_2010_p26-231580.xml&headline=Flight%20Tests%20Of%20Next%20F-35%20Block%20Underway "Flight Tests Of Next F-35 Block Underway"]. ''Aviation Week'', 12 June 2010. Retrieved 12 June 2010. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} In 2010, Pentagon officials discovered that additional software may be needed.Cox, Bob. [http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/11/21/2649040/pentagon-officials-to-meet-to.html "Pentagon officials to meet to address F-35 program's problems"]. ''[[Star-Telegram]]'', 21 November 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122044240/http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/11/21/2649040/pentagon-officials-to-meet-to.html |date=22 November 2010 }} General [[Norton Schwartz]] has said that the software is the biggest factor that might delay the USAF's initial operational capability.Reed, John. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2010/11/23/schwartz-concerned-about-f-35a-delays/ "Schwartz Concerned About F-35A Delays"]. ''DoD buzz'', 23 November 2010. In 2011, Michael Gilmore, Director of Operational Test & Evaluation, wrote that, "the F-35 mission systems software development and test is tending towards familiar historical patterns of extended development, discovery in flight test, and deferrals to later increments".Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/blogs/defense/index.jsp?plckController=Blog&plckBlogPage=BlogViewPost&newspaperUserId=27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A0941e5b4-a3c7-4406-85f8-151f2ef34d6b&plckScript=blogScript&plckElementId=blogDest "More F-35B Delays, Software Schedule At Risk"]. ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 13 January 2011. The electronic warfare and electro-optical systems are intended to detect and scan aircraft, allowing engagement or evasion of a hostile aircraft prior to being detected. The [[Lockheed Martin CATBird|CATbird avionics testbed aircraft]] has proved capable of detecting and [[Radar jamming and deception|jamming radars]], including the F-22's [[AN/APG-77]].David A. Fulghum, Bill Sweetman, Bradley Perrett and Robert Wall. "Stealthy Chinese J-20 Vulnerable". ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 14 January 2011. The F-35 was previously considered a platform for the [[Next Generation Jammer]]; attention shifted to using unmanned aircraft in this capacity instead.Fulghum, David. "New Plan: NGJ To Go Unmanned". ''Aviation Week'', 25 January 2012. Several subsystems use Xilinx FPGAs;{{cite web|url=http://www.avionics-intelligence.com/articles/2013/06/ai-f35-fpgas.html|title=Tens of thousands of Xilinx FPGAs to be supplied by Lockheed Martin for F-35 Joint Strike Fighter avionics.|publisher=}} these COTS components enable supply refreshes from the commercial sector and fleet software upgrades for the [[software-defined radio]] systems. Lockheed Martin's Dave Scott stated that sensor fusion boosts engine thrust and oil efficiency, increasing the aircraft's range.{{cite news|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20140725000012&cid=1101&MainCatID=0 |title=Japan needs to close bargain F-35 deal quickly |date=25 July 2014 |website=wantchinatimes.com |accessdate=24 July 2014 |df= }}{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Air Force official [[Ellen M. Pawlikowski]] has proposed using the F-35 to control and coordinate multiple [[unmanned combat aerial vehicle]]s (UCAVs). Using its sensors and communications equipment, a single F-35 could orchestrate an attack made by up to 20 armed UCAVs.[http://breakingdefense.com/2014/12/pawlikowski-on-air-force-offset-strategy-f-35s-flying-drone-fleets/ Pawlikowski On Air Force Offset Strategy: F-35s Flying Drone Fleets] – Breakingdefense.com, 15 December 2014 === Helmet-mounted display system === [[File:F-35 Helmet Mounted Display System.jpg|thumb|VSI Helmet-mounted display system for the F-35]] The F-35 does not need to be physically pointing at its target for weapons to be successful.[https://www.youtube.com/user/F35JSFVideos#play/uploads/7/CwvnhFgzIKI "F-35 Distributed Aperture System EO DAS"]. YouTube. Retrieved 23 November 2009. Sensors can track and target a nearby aircraft from any orientation, provide the information to the pilot through their helmet (and therefore visible no matter which way the pilot is looking), and provide the [[seeker-head]] of a missile with sufficient information. Recent missile types provide a much greater ability to pursue a target regardless of the launch orientation, called "High Off-Boresight" capability. Sensors use combined radio frequency and infra red (SAIRST) to continually track nearby aircraft while the pilot's [[helmet-mounted display]] system (HMDS) displays and selects targets; the helmet system replaces the display-suite-mounted [[head-up display]] used in earlier fighters.{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/260482/f+35-helmet-display-system-to-scare-the-bejeezus-out-of-enemies|title=F-35 Helmet Display System To Scare the Bejeezus Out of Enemies.|work=Gizmodo}} Each helmet costs $400,000.{{cite news|last1=Davenport|first1=Christian|title=Meet the most fascinating part of the F-35: The $400,000 helmet|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/04/01/meet-the-most-fascinating-part-of-the-f-35-the-400000-helmet/|website=WashingtonPost.com|accessdate=August 2, 2015}} The F-35's systems provide the edge in the "observe, orient, decide, and act" [[OODA loop]]; stealth and advanced sensors aid in observation (while being difficult to observe), automated target tracking helps in orientation, sensor fusion simplifies decision making, and the aircraft's controls allow the pilot to keep their focus on the targets, rather than the controls of their aircraft."JSF: the first complete ‘OODA Loop’ aircraft". ''Australian Defence Business Review'', December 2006, p. 23.{{efn|Quote: "Brigadier Davis was more forthright in his comments to media in Canberra, saying the ‘Raptor’ lacks some of the key sensors and the enhanced man-machine interface of the F-35".}} Problems with the Vision Systems International helmet-mounted display led Lockheed Martin-[[Elbit Systems]] to issue a draft specification for alternative proposals in early 2011, to be based around the Anvis-9 [[night vision]] goggles.Warwick, Graham. "Lockheed Weighs Alternate F-35 Helmet Display". ''Aviation Week'', 21 April 2011. [[BAE Systems]] was selected to provide the alternative system in late 2011.[https://archive.is/20130128074847/http://www.marketwatch.com/story/lockheed-martin-selects-bae-systems-to-supply-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-jsf-helmet-display-solution-2011-10-10 "Lockheed Martin Selects BAE Systems to Supply F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Helmet Display Solution"]. ''BAE Systems'', 10 October 2011. The BAE Systems alternative helmet was to include all the features of the VSI system.Szondy, David. [http://www.gizmag.com/f-35-helmet-display-bae/20216/ "BAE Systems to provide new helmet display for F-35 pilots"]. ''Gizmag'', 21 October 2011. However, adopting the alternative helmet would have required a cockpit redesign,Carey, Bill. [http://www.ainonline.com/aviation-news/singapore-air-show/2012-02-15/bae-drives-dual-approach-fixing-f-35-helmet-display-issues "BAE Drives Dual Approach To Fixing F-35 Helmet Display Issues"]. ''AINonline ''. 15 February 2012. but in 2013 development on the alternative helmet was halted because of progress on the baseline helmet.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-jpo-drops-development-of-bae-alternative-helmet-391623/ |title=F-35 JPO drops development of BAE alternative helmet |work=flightglobal.com |date=10 October 2013 |accessdate=29 April 2014 |first=Dave |last=Majumdar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429220250/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-jpo-drops-development-of-bae-alternative-helmet-391623/ |archivedate=29 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} In 2011, Lockheed Martin-Elbit granted VSI a contract to fix the vibration, jitter, night-vision and sensor display problems in their helmet-mounted display.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120430225851/http://www.dailymarkets.com/stock/2011/11/17/lockheed-martin-awards-f-35-contract/ "Lockheed Martin Awards F-35 Contract"]. ''Zacks Investment Research'', 17 November 2011. A speculated potential improvement is the replacement of Intevac’s ISIE-10 day/night camera with the newer ISIE-11 model.Jean, Grace V. [http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2011/August/Pages/NewSensorAimstoGiveF-35Pilotsa%E2%80%98WindowIntotheNight%E2%80%99.aspx "New Sensor Aims to Give F-35 Pilots a ‘Window Into the Night’"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721122642/http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2011/August/Pages/NewSensorAimstoGiveF-35Pilotsa%E2%80%98WindowIntotheNight%E2%80%99.aspx |date=21 July 2011 }} ''National Defense Magazine'', August 2011. In October 2012, Lockheed Martin-Elbit stated that progress had been made in resolving the technical issues of the helmet-mounted display, and cited positive reports from night flying tests; it had been questioned whether the helmet system allows pilots enough visibility at night to carry out precision tasks.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/10/30/lockheed-fighter-helmet-idUSL5E8LUJ4320121030 "Lockheed Cites Good Reports on Night Flights of F-35 Helmet"]. ''Reuters.com'', 30 October 2012. In 2013, in spite of continuing problems with the helmet display, the F-35B model completed 19 nighttime vertical landings on board the USS ''Wasp'' at sea,{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/29/lockheed-fighter-testing-idUSL2N0GU03Z20130829|title=U.S. Marines see progress in F-35 testing despite challenges.|work=Reuters | date=29 August 2013}} by using the DAS instead of the helmet's built-in night vision capabilities, which offer at best 20/35 vision.{{cite web |url=http://insidedefense.com/Inside-the-Navy/Inside-the-Navy-09/02/2013/f-35b-pilots-conduct-night-shipboard-landing-without-night-vision/menu-id-81.html |title=F-35B Pilots Conduct Night Shipboard Landing Without Night-Vision |date=9 February 2013 |website=Inside the Navy |publisher=Inside Washington Publishers |accessdate=19 September 2013}}{{dead link|date=July 2016}} In October 2013, development of the alternate helmet was halted. The current Gen 2 helmet is expected to meet the requirements to declare, in July 2015, that the F-35 has obtained initial operational capability. Beginning in 2016 with low rate initial production (LRIP) lot 7, the program will introduce a Gen 3 helmet that features an improved night vision camera, new liquid crystal displays, automated alignment and other software enhancements. In July 2015, an F-35 pilot commented that the helmet may have been one of the issues that the F-35 faced while dogfighting against an F-16 during a test; "The helmet was too large for the space inside the canopy to adequately see behind the aircraft. There were multiple occasions when the bandit would've been visible (not blocked by the seat) but the helmet prevented getting in a position to see him (behind the high side of the seat, around the inside of the seat, or high near the lift vector)".{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/damning-report-on-f-35s-dogfighting-problems-2015-7|title=Damning report on F-35's dogfighting problems – Business Insider|date=2 July 2015|work=Business Insider|accessdate=31 July 2015}} === Maintenance === The program's maintenance concept is for any F-35 to be maintained in any F-35 maintenance facility and that all F-35 parts in all bases will be globally tracked and shared as needed.[http://www.sldinfo.com/?p=18843 "F-35, Maintenance and the Challenge of Service Standardization"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110704140548/http://www.sldinfo.com/?p=18843 |date=4 July 2011 }}. ''Second Line of Defense'', 9 June 2011. The commonality between the different variants has allowed the USMC to create their first aircraft maintenance Field Training Detachment to directly apply the lessons of the USAF to their F-35 maintenance operations.Hawkins, Dan. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2012/07/mil-120727-afns01.htm "F-35 maintenance training spawns USMC's first air FTD"]. ''USMC'', 27 July 2012. The aircraft has been designed for ease of maintenance, with 95% of all field replaceable parts "one deep" where nothing else has to be removed to get to the part in question. For instance the ejection seat can be replaced without removing the canopy, the use of low-maintenance [[electro-hydrostatic actuator]]s instead of hydraulic systems and an all-composite skin without the fragile coatings found on earlier stealth aircraft.Clark, Colin. [http://defense.aol.com/2011/11/03/why-lockheed-thinks-f-35-beats-boeings-f-18/ "Why Lockheed Thinks F-35 Beats Boeing's F-18"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107070211/http://defense.aol.com/2011/11/03/why-lockheed-thinks-f-35-beats-boeings-f-18 |date=7 November 2011 }} ''Aol Defense'', 3 November 2011. The F-35 Joint Program Office has stated that the aircraft has received good reviews from pilots and maintainers, suggesting it is performing better than its predecessors did at a similar stage of development, and that the stealth type has proved relatively stable from a maintenance standpoint. This reported improvement is attributed to better maintenance training, as F-35 maintainers have received far more extensive instruction at this early stage of the program than on the [[F-22 Raptor]]. The F-35's stealth coatings are much easier to work with than those used on the Raptor. Cure times for coating repairs are lower and many of the fasteners and access panels are not coated, further reducing the workload for maintenance crews. Some of the F-35's radar-absorbent materials are baked into the jet's composite skin, which means its stealthy signature is not easily degraded.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-air-force-praises-early-performance-of-lockheed-martin-f-35-378578/ "US Air Force praises early performance of Lockheed Martin F-35"].''Flightglobal.com'', 6 November 2012. It is still harder to maintain (because of the need to preserve its stealth characteristics) than fourth-generation aircraft.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/stealth-isnt-becoming-obsolete-anytime-soon-379671/ "Stealth isn’t becoming obsolete anytime soon"]. ''Flight International'', 30 November 2012. Retrieved 1 December 2012. However, the [[DOT&E]] Report on the F-35 program published in January 2015 determined that the plane has not, in fact, reached any of the nine reliability measures the program was supposed to achieve by this point in its development and that the Joint Program Office has been re-categorizing failure incidents to make the plane look more reliable than it actually is. Further, the complexity of maintaining the F-35 means that, currently, none of the Services are ready to keep it in working order and instead "rely heavily on contractor support and unacceptable workarounds". DOT&E found that the program achieved 61 percent of planned flight hours and that the average rate of availability was as low as 28 percent for the F-35A and 33 percent for the F-35B. The program created a new "modeled achievable" flight hour projection "since low availability was preventing the full use of bed-down plan flight hours". According to the Assistant Secretary of the Air Force for Financial Management, in FY2014, each non-test F-35 flew only 7.7 hours per month, which amounts to approximately one sortie every 5.5 days—for combat purposes, a sortie rate so low as to be crippling. Mean flight hours between removal (MFHBR) have increased, but are still only 59 percent to 65 percent of the required threshold. DOT&E found that mean corrective maintenance time for critical failures got worse for the F-35A and the F-35C over the last year. Structural cracking is also proving to be a recurring and enduring problem that is not yet resolved.{{cite web | url=http://www.dote.osd.mil/pub/reports/FY2014/pdf/dod/2014f35jsf.pdf | title=FY 2014 Programs: F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) |date=15 January 2015 | publisher=The Office of The Director, Operational Test And Evaluation (DOT&E)}} == Operational history == === Testing === The first F-35A (designated AA-1) was rolled out in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], on 19 February 2006. In September 2006, the first engine run of the [[Pratt & Whitney F135|F135]] in an airframe took place."Mighty F-35 Lightning II Engine Roars to Life". ''Lockheed Martin'', 20 September 2006. On 15 December 2006, the F-35A completed its maiden flight.[https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/7074259f3965fd0985256f43007b0964/7f70d66a0aaef181852573540049ead4?OpenDocument "F-35 First Flight"].{{dead link|date=November 2013}} TeamJSF.com. Retrieved 10 October 2007. A modified [[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737–300]], the [[Lockheed Martin CATBird]] has been used as an avionics test-bed for the F-35 program, including a duplication of the cockpit. The first F-35B (designated BF-1) made its maiden flight on 11 June 2008, piloted by BAE Systems' test pilot Graham Tomlinson. February 2013 |date=22 February 2013}} On 28 February 2013, the grounding was lifted after an investigation concluded that the cracks in that particular engine resulted from stressful testing, including excessive heat for a prolonged period during flight, and did not reflect a fleetwide problem.Mount, Mike. [http://myfox8.com/2013/03/01/military-clears-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-to-fly/ "Military Clears F-35 Joint Strike Fighter to Fly"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005929/http://myfox8.com/2013/03/01/military-clears-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-to-fly/ |date=5 March 2016 }}. CNN, 1 March 2013.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35s-cleared-to-resume-flight-operations-382909/ "F-35s cleared to resume flight operations"]. Flight International, 28 February 2013. The F-35C Lightning II carrier variant Joint Strike Fighter conducted its first carrier-based night flight operations aboard an aircraft carrier off the coast of San Diego on 13 November 2014.{{cite web | url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84456 | title=F-35C Completes First Night Flight Aboard Aircraft Carrier | publisher=US Navy | date=13 November 2014 | accessdate=2014-11-28}} On 5 June 2015, the U.S. Air Education and Training Command Accident Investigation Board reported that catastrophic engine failure had led to the destruction of an Air Force F-35A assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida, on 23 June 2014. The third-stage forward integral arm of a rotor had fractured and broke free during the takeoff roll. Pieces cut through the engine's fan case, engine bay, internal fuel tank and hydraulic and fuel lines before leaving through the aircraft's upper fuselage. Leaked fuel and hydraulic fluid ignited the fire, which destroyed the rear two-thirds of the aircraft. The destruction of the airframe resulted in the cancelation of the F-35's international debut at the 2014 [[Farnborough Airshow]] in England, the temporary grounding of the F-35 fleet{{cite web | url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/story/military/2015/06/05/air-force-investigation-june-2014-f35-fire/28535269/ | title=AF investigation: Catastrophic engine failure caused F-35 fire | publisher=Airforce News | date=5 June 2015 | accessdate=5 June 2015}} and ongoing restrictions in the flight envelope.{{cite news|last1=Majumdar|first1=Dave|last2=Kjelgaard|first2=Chris|url=http://nationalinterest.org/feature/f-35-needs-bigger-more-powerful-engine-12491|title=F-35 Needs a Bigger, More Powerful Engine|work=The National Interest|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=29 July 2016}} On 19 June 2015 the [[RAF]] successfully launched two 500 lb [[Paveway IV]] precision-guided bombs, making the test the first time non-US munitions were deployed by the aircraft.{{cite news| title='F-35 Tests British Paveway IV Bomb'| url=http://awin.aviationweek.com/AWINLogin/tabid/1083/Default.aspx?returnurl=%2fArticlesStory.aspx%3fid%3dd5f973b4-2217-4450-98df-4519bf7ac35e| accessdate=24 June 2015| newspaper=''Aviation Week''| date=19 June 2015}} The US Marines declared the aircraft had met initial operational capability on 31 July 2015, despite shortcomings in night operations, communications, software and weapons carriage capabilities.{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/better-five-years-late-than-never-u-s-marines-finally-ready-to-declare-f-35b-ready-for-limited-combat-duty|title=Better five years late than never: U.S. Marines finally ready to declare F-35B ready for limited combat duty|author1=Tony Capaccio |author2=Julie Johnsson |author3=Bloomberg News |date=31 July 2015|work=National Post|accessdate=31 July 2015}} However, [[J. Michael Gilmore]], director of the Pentagon’s Operational Test and Evaluation Office, criticized the operational trials as not valid. In an internal memo, Gilmore concluded "the exercise was so flawed that it 'was not an operational test … in either a formal or informal sense of the term.' Furthermore, the test 'did not—and could not—demonstrate' that the version of the F-35 that was evaluated 'is ready for real-world operational deployments, given the way the event was structured.'"{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/09/15/pentagon-weapons-tester-calls-f-35-evaluation-into-question|title=Pentagon weapons tester calls F-35 evaluation into question|author=Christian Davenport|date=15 September 2015|work=Washington Post|accessdate=29 September 2015}} On 11 April 2016 the Joint Program Office confirmed that the [[Royal Netherlands Air Force]] (RNLAF) had cleared its [[KDC-10]] aerial tanker to refuel the F-35, paving the way for the fighter’s international public debut at the RNLAF’s ''Open Dagen'' (Open Days) at Leeuwarden on June 10–11, 2016. The testing required the fighter to refuel in daylight, dusk and night, with 30,000 lb. of fuel being transferred during the tests.{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/netherlands-tanker-cleared-refuel-f-35? |title=Netherlands Tanker Cleared To Refuel F-35 |date=11 April 2016 |work=Aviation Week}} The Israel Air Force declared its F-35 fleet operationally capable on December 6, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.f35.com/news/detail/israel-declares-f-35i-adir-combat-capable|title=Israel Declares F-35I Adir Combat Capable – F-35 Lightning II|website=F-35 Lightning II|accessdate=9 December 2017}} === Training === In 2011, the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation warned that the USAF's plan to start unmonitored flight training "risks the occurrence of a serious mishap".Schwellenbach, Nick. [http://www.pogo.org/resources/national-security/dod-memo-concerns-regarding-jsf-operational-utility-evaluation-training-flights.html "Concerns Regarding Plans for the Joint Strike Fighter to Begin Training Flights and Conduct an Operational Utility Evaluation"]. ''POGO'', 31 October 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030071648/http://www.pogo.org/resources/national-security/dod-memo-concerns-regarding-jsf-operational-utility-evaluation-training-flights.html |date=30 October 2012 }} The leaders of the [[United States Senate Committee on Armed Services]] called on Defense Secretary [[Leon Panetta]] to address the issue.[http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-s-senators-press-panetta-to-review-f-35-training-safety.html "U.S. Senators Press Panetta to Review F-35 Training Safety"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113195802/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-s-senators-press-panetta-to-review-f-35-training-safety.html |date=13 January 2012 }} ''Bloomberg News'', 9 December 2011. Despite the objections, expanded trial flights began in September 2012.Capaccio, Tony. ''Bloomberg BusinessWeek'', 28 September 2012.
