Retrieved 5 May 2012 The aircraft were restricted to basic maneuvers with no tactical training allowed.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/first-air-national-guard-pilot-starts-transition-to-f-35-374470/ "First Air National Guard pilot starts transition to F-35"]. ''Flight Magazine'', 17 July 2012. On 24 August 2012, an F-35 flew its 200th sortie while at Eglin Air Force Base, flown by a Marine pilot. The pilot said, "The aircraft have matured dramatically since the early days. The aircraft are predictable and seem to be maintainable, which is good for the sortie production rate. Currently, the flight envelope for the F-35 is very, very restricted, but there are signs of improvement there too". The F-35s at the base no longer need to fly with a chase aircraft and are operating in a normal two-ship element.[http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/eglin-f-35s-fly-200th-sortie-375794/ "Eglin F-35s fly 200th sortie"]. ''Flight International'', 24 August 2012. On 21 August 2012, [[J. Michael Gilmore]] wrote that he would not approve the Operational Test and Evaluation master plan until his concerns about electronic warfare testing, budget and concurrency were addressed.[http://defense.aol.com/2012/08/28/pentagons-testing-czar-questions-f-35-programs-ote-plan/ "Pentagon's Testing Czar Questions F-35 Program's OTE Plan"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120831025218/http://defense.aol.com/2012/08/28/pentagons-testing-czar-questions-f-35-programs-ote-plan/ |date=31 August 2012 }} ''Aol Defense'', 28 August 2012. On 7 September 2012, the Pentagon failed to approve a comprehensive operational testing plan for the F-35.Shalal-Esa, Andrea. [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/11/us-lockheed-fighter-idUSBRE88A04A20120911 "More problems raised at Pentagon F-35 fighter review"]. Reuters, 10 September 2012. Instead, on 10 September 2012, the USAF began an operational utility evaluation (OUE) of the F-35A entire system, including logistical support and maintenance, maintenance training, pilot training, and pilot execution.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-to-start-f-35-operational-utility-evaluation-on-10-september-376217/ "USAF to start F-35 operational utility evaluation on 10 September"]. ''Flight International'', 7 September 2012. By 1 October, the OUE was reported as "proceeding smoothly", pilots started on simulators prior to flying on 26 October.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/f-35-operational-utility-evaluation-proceeding-smoothly-377163/ "F-35 operational utility evaluation proceeding smoothly"]. ''Flightglobal.com'', 1 October 2012. The OUE was completed on 14 November with the 24th flight, the four pilots involved having completed six flights each.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-unit-completes-f-35-oue-activity-379117/ |title=USAF unit completes F-35 OUE activity |work=flightglobal.com |date=16 November 2012 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Dave |last=Majumdar |others=Image Credit: Lockheed Martin |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525031901/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-unit-completes-f-35-oue-activity-379117/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} During the Low Rate Initial Production (LRIP) phase of the aircraft, the U.S. had taken a tri-service approach to developing tactics and procedures for the F-35 using flight simulators prior to the type entering service. Simulated flights had tested the flight controls' effectiveness, helping to discover technical problems and refine aircraft design.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/simulation-plays-vital-role-in-building-f-35-tactics-and-aircraft-development-379336/ "Simulation plays vital role in building F-35 tactics and aircraft development"]. ''Flight International'', 21 November 2012. Maintenance personnel have discovered that it is often possible to correct deficiencies in the F-35, which is a software-defined aircraft, simply by rebooting the aircraft's software and onboard systems.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-air-force-praises-early-performance-of-lockheed-martin-f-35-378578/ "US Air Force praises early performance of Lockheed Martin F-35"]. ''Flight International'', 6 November 2012. Air Force pilot training F-35A began in January 2013 at Eglin Air Force Base; the program currently has a maximum capacity of 100 military pilots and 2,100 maintainer students.[http://militarytimes.com/news/2012/12/air-force-f35-pilot-training-starts-next-month-eglin-121712/ "F-35 pilot training starts next month at Eglin>"] Militarytimes.com, 17 December 2012. On 23 June 2014, an F-35A experienced a fire in the engine area during its takeoff at Eglin AFB. In response, the Pentagon's Joint Program Office halted training in all F-35 models the next day,{{cite news|last1=Hennigan|first1=William J.|title=U.S. military grounds all F-35 jets after fire at Florida base |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/aerospace/la-fi-f-35-fire-grounded-20140626-story.html |publisher=The Los Angeles Times |date=26 June 2014 |accessdate=2 July 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hennigan|first1=William J.|title=F-35 fighter jets to resume flights after fire led to grounding|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-f35-plane-fire-20140625-story.html|accessdate=2 July 2014|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|date=24 June 2014}} and on 3 July, the F-35 fleet was formally grounded.{{cite web|last1=Butler|first1=Amy|title=Blade 'Rubbing' At Root of F-35A Engine Fire|url=http://aviationweek.com/farnborough-2014/blade-rubbing-root-f-35a-engine-fire|website=Aviation Week|publisher=Penton Media|accessdate=14 July 2014}} The fleet was returned to flight on 15 July,{{cite news |url=http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2014/07/breaking-f-35-cleared-for-flight-2/?sf3711164=1 |title=BREAKING: F-35 Cleared For Flight |last1=Mehta |first1=Aaron |date=15 July 2014 |website=defensenews.com |publisher=Defense News |accessdate=15 July 2014}} but the engine inspection regimen caused the aircraft's debut at the Farnborough 2014 Air Show to be canceled.{{cite news |url=http://breakingdefense.com/2014/07/no-f-35s-coming-to-farnborough-safety-first-says-secdef-hagel/ |title= NO F-35s Coming To Farnborough; Safety First, Says SecDef Hagel |last1=Clark |first1=Colin |date=15 July 2014 |website=breakingdefense.com |publisher=Breaking Media, Inc. |accessdate=15 July 2014}}[https://archive.is/20140717195739/http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140715/DEFREG02/307150027 "Pentagon: F-35 Will Not Go to Farnborough"]. Defense News At Red Flag 2017 the F-35 scored a kill ratio of 15:1 against an F-16 aggressor squadron.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/f-35-slaughters-competition-red-flag-2017-2|title=The F-35 slaughtered the competition in its latest test|work=businessinsider.com|accessdate=22 February 2017}} === Basing plans for future U.S. F-35s === On 9 December 2010, a media report stated that the "USMC will base 216 F-35Bs on the East Coast and 184 of them on the West Coast, documents showed". This report continued: "[[MCAS Cherry Point|Cherry Point]] will get 128 jets to form eight squadrons; [[MCAS Beaufort|Beaufort]] will have three squadrons and a pilot training center using 88 aircraft; [[MCAS Miramar|Miramar]] will form six operational squadrons with 96 jets and 88 F-35s will go to [[MCAS Yuma|Yuma]] for five operational squadrons with an additional test and evaluation unit"."Military plans to send jets to S.C., N.C., Calif., Ariz". The Associated Press, 9 December 2010, Susanne M. Schafer. In 2011, the [[United States Marine Corps|USMC]] and USN signed an agreement that the USMC will purchase 340 F-35B and 80 F-35C fighters. The five squadrons of USMC F-35Cs would be assigned to Navy carriers while F-35Bs would be used ashore.Daniel, Lisa. [http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63158 "Plan Improves Navy, Marine Corps Air Capabilities"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529052624/http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=63158 |date=29 May 2011 }} ''[[American Forces Press Service]]'', 14 March 2011.Cavas, Christopher P. [http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2011/03/navy-more-marines-to-fly-f35c-031411w/ "More Marines to fly carrier-variant JSFs"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428154152/http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/2011/03/navy-more-marines-to-fly-f35c-031411w/ |date=28 April 2011 }} ''[[Marine Corps Times]]'', 14 March 2011. In February 2014, the [[U.S. Air Force]] announced that the first [[Air National Guard]] unit to fly the new F-35 Lightning II will be the [[158th Fighter Wing]] of the Vermont Air National Guard based at the Burlington Air Guard Station. The 158th currently flies [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]]s, which are nearing the end of their useful service lives. Burlington Air Guard Station is expected to receive 18 F-35As, replacing the 18 F-16 Fighting Falcons currently assigned. The F-35A is expected to arrive in 2020.{{cite web|url=http://www.158fw.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123401944/ |title=Feature – VTANG first Air Guard Base to receive F-35A |first=Capt. Dyana |last=Allen |work=af.mil |accessdate=24 November 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160119122927/http://www.158fw.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123401944%2F |archivedate=19 January 2016 |df= }} On 11 March 2014, the first F-35A Lightning II assigned to [[Luke Air Force Base]] arrived at the base. 16 F-35s are to be delivered to the base by the end of 2014, with 144 Lightning IIs to be stationed there, arriving over the course of the next decade.{{cite web|url=http://www.deagel.com/news/First-of-144-F-35A-Lightning-II-Stealth-Jets-Arrives-at-Luke-AFB_n000012469.aspx |title=First of 144 F-35A Lightning II Stealth Jets Arrives at Luke AFB |work=deagel.com |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525034824/http://www.deagel.com/news/First-of-144-F-35A-Lightning-II-Stealth-Jets-Arrives-at-Luke-AFB_n000012469.aspx |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473693/first-f-35-lightning-ii-arrives-at-luke-afb |title=First F-35 Lightning II arrives at Luke AFB > U.S. Air Force > Article Display |work=af.mil |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |author= U.S. Air Force |others=Image credits: U.S. Air Force photo/Jim Hazeltine, 2xU.S. Air Force photo/Staff Sgt. Darlene Seltmann |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525035117/http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/473693/first-f-35-lightning-ii-arrives-at-luke-afb |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 8 January 2015, the Royal Air Force base [[RAF Lakenheath]] in the UK was chosen as the first base in Europe to station two American F-35 squadrons, following an announcement by [[the Pentagon]]. 48 F-35s, making up 2 squadrons, will add to the [[48th Fighter Wing]]'s already existing [[F-15C]] and [[F-15E Strike Eagle]] jets.[http://theaviationist.com/2015/01/09/uk-base-selected-to-host-first-u-s-f-35-jets-in-europe/ "RAF Lakenheath was selected as the first base to host USAFE F-35s"]. ''The Aviationist'', Retrieved January 13, 2015. === Combat operation === On 22 May 2018, the Israeli Air Force chief [[Amikam Norkin]] said that the Israeli Air Force had employed the F-35 in two attacks on two different battle fronts, the first time any F-35 was used in a combat operation by any country.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lockheed-f35-israel/israel-says-it-is-the-first-country-to-use-u-s-made-f-35-in-combat-idUSKCN1IN0ON "Israel says it is the first country to use U.S.-made F-35 in combat".]. Reuters, 22 May 2018.[https://theaviationist.com/?p=55011 Everything We Know (And Don’t Know) About Israel Launching World’s First Air Strikes Using The F-35 Stealth Aircraft] The Aviationist, 22 May 2018. The air force chief said the plane had been flown "all over the Middle East", and showed conference participants photos of an Israeli F-35 flying over Beirut in a daylight flight.[https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/this-is-the-israeli-army-s-photo-of-an-f-35-over-beirut-1.6114446 A Message of Superiority: This Is the Israeli Army's Photo of an F-35 Over Beirut] Yaniv Kubovich May 23, 2018, Haaretz On 27 September 2018, A [[United States Marines Corps]] F-35B was used against a [[Taliban]] target in Afghanistan, the first U.S. combat employment. The F-35B took off from the [[USS Essex (LHD-2)|USS ''Essex'']] amphibious assault ship in the [[Arabian Sea]].{{cite web |url= https://www.yahoo.com/news/lockheed-f-35-jet-used-u-combat-first-170619430--finance.html |title=F-35 jet used by U.S. in combat for first time |publisher= yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=27 September 2018}} == Accidents == On 23 June 2014, an F-35A preparing to take off on a training flight at Eglin Air Force Base experienced a fire in the engine area. The pilot escaped unharmed. The accident caused all training to be halted on 25 June, and all flights halted on 3 July. During the incident investigation, engine parts from the burned aircraft were discovered on the runway, indicating it was a substantial engine failure.{{cite news|last1=Shalal|first1=Andrea|title=Engine pieces found on runway after F-35 fire – sources|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/27/lockheed-fighter-engine-idUSL2N0P818G20140627|accessdate=2 July 2014|work=Reuters.Com|agency=Reuters|issue=US Edition|publisher=Thomson Reuters|date=27 June 2014}} The fleet was returned to flight on 15 July with restrictions in the flight envelope. Preliminary findings suggests that excessive rubbing of the engine fan blades created increased stress and wear and eventually resulted in catastrophic failure of the fan.{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140713/SHOWSCOUT15/307130026/Kendall-Fan-Blade-Rubbing-Cause-F-35-Fire|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140806185545/http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140713/SHOWSCOUT15/307130026/Kendall-Fan-Blade-Rubbing-Cause-F-35-Fire|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 August 2014|title=Kendall: Fan-Blade Rubbing Cause of F-35 Fire|work=Defense News|accessdate=21 September 2014}} In early June 2015, the USAF Air Education and Training Command (AETC) issued its official report on the incident. It found that the incident was the result of a failure of the third stage rotor of the engine's fan module. The report explained that "pieces of the failed rotor arm cut through the engine's fan case, the engine bay, an internal fuel tank, and hydraulic and fuel lines before exiting through the aircraft's upper fuselage". Pratt & Whitney, the engine manufacturer, developed two remedies to the problem. The first is an extended "rub-in" to increase the gap between the second stator and the third rotor integral arm seal. The second is the redesign to pre-trench the stator. Both were scheduled for completion by early 2016. Cost of the problem was estimated at US$50 million. All aircraft resumed operations within 25 days of the incident.{{cite journal|last1=Malenic|first1=Marina|title=Pentagon releases report on F-35 engine failure|journal=IHS Janes Defence Weekly|date=17 June 2015|volume=52|issue=24|page=13}} On 28 September 2018, a USMC F-35B crashed near [[Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort]], [[South Carolina]] after the pilot ejected safely. This was the first F-35 crash.{{cite web |url=https://www.stripes.com/news/us/f-35b-lightning-ii-fighter-jet-crashes-pilot-ejects-in-south-carolina-1.549535 |title=F-35B Lightning II fighter jet crashes, pilot ejects in South Carolina |publisher= |work=Stripes.com |accessdate=28 September 2018}}[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/f-35-crashes-for-the-first-time-in-the-jets-17-year-history-pilot-ejects-safely/2018/09/28/9faaeff4-c341-11e8-8f06-009b39c3f6dd_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.9ed720e31946] == Procurement and international participation == {{Main|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II procurement}} [[File:F-35 potential purchasers.PNG|thumb|upright=1.6|Participant nations:
{{legend|#000075|Primary customer: United States}} {{legend|#750012|Level 1 partner: United Kingdom}} {{legend|#227600|Level 2 partners: Italy and the Netherlands}} {{legend|#da8901|Level 3 partners: Australia, Canada, Denmark, Norway, and Turkey}} {{legend|#75edd4|Security Cooperative Participants: Israel and Singapore}} ]] While the United States is the primary customer and financial backer, along with the United Kingdom, Italy, the Netherlands, Canada, Turkey, Australia, Norway, and Denmark have agreed to contribute US$4.375 billion towards development costs.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35-int.htm "F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Lightning II – International Partners"]. ''Global Security''. Retrieved 7 April 2010. Total development costs are estimated at more than US$40 billion. The purchase of an estimated 2,400 aircraft is expected to cost an additional US$200 billion.Merle, Renae. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A38236-2005Mar15.html "GAO Questions Cost Of Joint Strike Fighter"]. ''The Washington Post'', 15 March 2005. The initial plan was that the nine major partner nations would acquire over 3,100 F-35s through 2035.[http://www.jsf.mil/downloads/documents/JSF_PSFD_MOU_-_Update_4_2010.PDF "Estimated JSF Air Vehicle Procurement Quantities"]. ''JSF.mil'', Updated as of April 2010. Sales to partner nations are made through the Pentagon's [[Foreign Military Sales]] program.Tae-hoon, Lee. [https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2012/03/205_106346.html "Seoul fears delivery delays of F-35 jets"]. ''The Korea Times'', 6 March 2012. There are three levels of international participation.[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/F-35-Lightning-The-Joint-Strike-Fighter-Program-2012-07501/ "F-35 Lightning: The Joint Strike Fighter Program, 2012"]. ''Defense Industry Daily'', 30 October 2012. The levels generally reflect financial stake in the program, the amount of technology transfer and subcontracts open for bid by national companies, and the order in which countries can obtain production aircraft. The United Kingdom is the sole "Level 1" partner, contributing US$2.5 billion, which was about 10% of the planned development costs[https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/75public/07CF737749FA9E5585256F3900720288?OpenDocument "JSF Global Partners"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071004212446/https://www.teamjsf.com/jsf/data.nsf/75public/07CF737749FA9E5585256F3900720288?OpenDocument |date=4 October 2007 }} teamjsf.com. Retrieved 30 March 2007. under the 1995 [[Memorandum of Understanding]] that brought the UK into the project."US, UK sign JAST agreement". ''Aerospace Daily'' New York: McGraw-Hill, 25 November 1995, p. 451. Level 2 partners are Italy, which is contributing US$1 billion; and the Netherlands, US$800 million. Level 3 partners are Turkey, US$195 million; Canada, US$160 million; Australia, US$144 million; Norway, US$122 million and Denmark, US$110 million. Israel and Singapore have joined as Security Cooperative Participants (SCP).Schnasi, Katherine V. [http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d04554.pdf "Joint Strike Fighter Acquisition: Observations on the Supplier Base"]. ''US Accounts Office''. Retrieved 8 February 2006.[http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/ad-ad.nsf/eng/ad03863.html "Industry Canada F-35 Joint Strike Fighter (JSF) Canada's Next Generation Fighter Capability"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922154022/http://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/ad-ad.nsf/eng/ad03863.html |date=22 September 2010}} ic.gc.ca. Retrieved 25 November 2010.''Combat Aircraft Monthly'', September 2010, p. 24. In particular, there are signs that the [[Republic of Singapore Air Force]] (RSAF) is interested, as the force has indicated that it is seriously evaluating a potential purchase{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-singapore-airshow-lockheed/singapore-seriously-evaluating-future-f-35-jet-purchase-lockheed-exec-idUSKBN1FS10R|title=Singapore 'seriously evaluating' future F-35 jet purchase -...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}} and the defense minister has indicated that an F-16 replacement will be announced soon.{{Cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/decision-on-f-16-fighter-jet-replacement-likely-in-next-few-months-ng-eng-hen|title=Decision on F-16 fighter jet replacement likely in next few months: Ng Eng Hen|last=hermesauto|date=2018-06-30|work=The Straits Times|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en}} Japan announced on 20 December 2011 its intent to purchase 42 F-35s with deliveries beginning in 2016 to replace the [[F-4 Phantom II]]; Japan seeks 38 F-35s, to be assembled domestically.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16259895 "US Lockheed Martin F-35 chosen as Japan fighter jet"]. BBC News, 20 December 2011. Retrieved: 20 December 2011. By 2012, many changes had occurred in the order book. Italy became the first country to announce a reduction of its overall fleet procurement, cutting its buy from 131 to 90 aircraft. Other nations reduced initial purchases or delayed orders while still intending to purchase the same final numbers. The United States canceled the initial purchase of 13 F-35s and postponed orders for another 179. The United Kingdom cut its initial order and delayed a decision on future orders. Australia decided to buy the [[Boeing F/A-18E/F Super Hornet]] as an interim measure. Turkey also cut its initial order of four aircraft to two, but confirmed plans to purchase 100 F-35As.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/23/turkey-f35-lockheed-idUSL5E8DN2IM20120223 "Update 1-Turkey keeps plan to buy 100 F-35 fighter jets"]. Reuters, 23 February 2012.[http://www.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=378853#.T-xxLsr4JfA "Turkey plans to buy 100 F-35 jet fighters"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120521004950/http://www.turkishpress.com/news.asp?id=378853#.T-xxLsr4JfA |date=21 May 2012 }} turkishpress.com, 24 February 2012. Turkey will buy four F-35s to be delivered in 2015 and 2016, while the order may be increased from 100 to 120 aircraft.[http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/141212/turkey-to-buy-two-planes-in-second-f-35-shipment.html "Turkey to Buy Two Planes in Second F-35 Shipment"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219015047/http://www.turkishweekly.net/news/141212/turkey-to-buy-two-planes-in-second-f-35-shipment.html |date=19 December 2013 }} ''turkishweekly.net,'' 4 September 2012. These changes resulted in increased procurement prices, and increased the likelihood of further cuts.Harper, Tim. [https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/1131391--tim-harper-the-conservatives-and-their-f-35-fairy-tale "Tim Harper: The Conservatives and their F-35 fairy tale"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', 14 February 2012.Vasarri, Chiara. [https://archive.is/20130118143224/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-02-15/italy-to-cut-f-35-fighter-jet-orders-as-part-of-defense-revamp.html "Italy to Cut F-35 Fighter Jet Orders as Part of Defense Revamp"]. ''Bloomberg Business Week'', 14 February 2012. On 3 April 2012, the [[Auditor General of Canada]] [[Michael Ferguson (Auditor General)|Michael Ferguson]] published a report outlining problems with [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Canadian procurement|Canada's procurement of the jet]], including misinformation over the final cost. According to the Auditor General, the government knowingly understated the final price of the 65 jets by $10 billion.Postmedia News. [http://www.canada.com/timeline+Canada+involvement+program/6419249/story.html "A timeline on Canada's involvement in the F-35 program"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410034623/http://www.canada.com/timeline%2BCanada%2Binvolvement%2Bprogram/6419249/story.html |date=10 April 2012 }} ''[[Canada.com]]'', 5 April 2012. Canada's Conservative government had stated it would not reduce its order, and anticipated a $75–80 million unit cost; the procurement was termed a "scandal" and "fiasco" by the media and faced a full review to determine any Canadian F-35 purchase.[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/video/video-mps-hold-mackay-to-account-in-f-35-scandal/article2392358/ "Video: MPs hold Mackay to account in F-35 scandal"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406082755/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/video/video-mps-hold-mackay-to-account-in-f-35-scandal/article2392358/ |date=6 April 2012 }}. [[The Canadian Press]] via ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', 4 April 2012.Coyne, Andrew. [http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/04/andrew-coyne-the-f-35-affair-is-a-fiasco-from-top-to-bottom/ "Peeling back the layers of misconduct in the F-35 fiasco"]. {{webarchive |url=https://archive.is/20130104003959/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/04/andrew-coyne-the-f-35-affair-is-a-fiasco-from-top-to-bottom/ |date=4 January 2013 }} ''[[National Post]]'', 4 April 2012.[http://www.cbc.ca/thenational/indepthanalysis/atissue/story/2012/04/05/thenational-atissue-040512.html "The F-35 Fiasco"]. ''[[CBC News]]'', 5 April 2012. On 13 December 2012, in a scathing editorial published by [[CBC News]], journalist [[Brian Stewart (journalist)|Brian Stewart]] termed the F-35 project a "global wrecking ball" for its runaway costs and lack of affordability for many participating nations.Stewart, Brian. [http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/12/12/f-vp-stewart-f35-jets.html "Super-costly F-35s, a global wrecking ball"]. ''[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]'', 13 December 2012. The Canadian government ultimately decided not to proceed with sole-sourced purchase of the fighter and commenced a competition to choose a different aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/blog/canada-cancels-f-35-procurement|title=Canada cancels F-35 procurement|website=aviationweek.com|accessdate=22 March 2018}} In May 2013, Lockheed Martin declared that Turkey is projected to earn $12 billion from licensed production of F-35 components.{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/f-35-project-to-earn-turkey-12-billion.aspx?pageID=238&nid=46581&NewsCatID=345 |title=F-35 project to ‘earn Turkey $12 billion’ |work=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=30 May 2013 |author= |agency=Reuters |others=Image credit: Reuters |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525035843/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/f-35-project-to-earn-turkey-12-billion.aspx?pageID=238&nid=46581&NewsCatID=345 |archivedate=25 May 2014 of secrecy.{{cite web |last1=Manson |first1=Katrina |last2=Pitel |first2=Laura |title=US Senate blocks F-35 sales to Turkey |url=https://www.ft.com/content/d3c7492c-7346-11e8-b6ad-3823e4384287 |website=www.ft.com |publisher=Financial Times |accessdate=19 June 2018}} == Variants == [[File:F-35 A B C Config.png|thumb|Configuration of the three original F-35 variants. [[CTOL]] for conventional take-off and landing, [[STOVL]] for short take-off and vertical-landing, and CV for carrier variant]] The F-35 is being built in three different main versions to suit various combat missions. === F-35A === The F-35A is the conventional takeoff and landing ([[CTOL]]) variant intended for the U.S. Air Force and other air forces. It is the smallest, lightest F-35 version and is the only variant equipped with an internal cannon, the [[GAU-12 Equalizer#GAU-22/A|GAU-22/A]]. This [[25 mm caliber|25 mm]] cannon is a development of the [[GAU-12 Equalizer|GAU-12]] carried by the USMC's [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|AV-8B Harrier II]]. It is designed for increased effectiveness against ground targets compared to the [[20 mm caliber|20 mm]] [[M61 Vulcan]] cannon carried by other USAF fighters. [[File:A U.S. Air Force pilot navigates an F-35A Lightning II aircraft assigned to the 58th Fighter Squadron, 33rd Fighter Wing into position to refuel with a KC-135 Stratotanker assigned to the 336th Air Refueling 130516-F-XL333-496.jpg|thumb|left|US Air Force F-35A maneuvers to refuel from a [[Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker|KC-135]].]] The F-35A is expected to match the F-16 in maneuverability and instantaneous high-g performance, and outperform it in stealth, payload, range on internal fuel, avionics, operational effectiveness, supportability, and survivability.Pike, John. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35a.htm "F-35A Joint Strike Fighter"]. Globalsecurity.org. Retrieved 23 November 2009. It is expected to match an F-16 that is carrying the usual external fuel tank in acceleration performance.[http://www.lockheedmartin.com/aeronautics/afa/beesley-interview.html "Flying The F-35: An Interview With Jon Beesley, F-35 Chief Test Pilot"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218222032/http://www.lockheedmartin.com/aeronautics/afa/beesley-interview.html |date=18 December 2014 }}. lockheedmartin.com. Retrieved 25 November 2010. The A variant is primarily intended to replace the USAF's [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon|F-16 Fighting Falcon]]. At one point it was also intended to replace the [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10 Thunderbolt II]] starting in 2028.Hebert, Adam J. [http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/July%202007/0707lightning.aspx "Lightning II: So Far, So Good"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221095128/http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/July%202007/0707lightning.aspx |date=21 February 2009 }} ''airforce-magazine.com'', Air Force Association, Volume 90, Issue 7, July 2007. Retrieved 3 December 2008.Laurenzo, Ron. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2003/030609-a-10-retire01.htm "Air Force: No Plan To Retire A-10"]. GlobalSecurity.org, Defense Weekly, 9 June 2003. Retrieved 3 December 2008. The F-35A can be outfitted to receive fuel via either of the two main aerial refueling methods; this was a consideration in the Canadian procurement and a deciding factor for the Japanese purchase.Waldron, Greg. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/in-focus-tokyo-casts-wary-eye-on-chinese-airpower-developments-375007/ "IN FOCUS: Tokyo casts wary eye on Chinese airpower developments"]. ''Flight International'', 2 August 2012.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/10/23/f-35-communication-problem.html "F-35s face communication problems in Arctic"]. The Canadian Press, 23 October 2011.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2012/06/19/lockheeds-comprehensive-qa-on-the-f-35/ "Lockheed’s comprehensive Q&A on the F-35"]. ''DoD Buzz'', 19 June 2012. On 18 December 2013, the Netherlands became the second partner country to operate the F-35A, when Maj. Laurens J.W. Vijge of the [[Royal Netherlands Air Force]] took off from Eglin Air Force Base.{{cite web|url= http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/first-royal-netherlands-air-force-f-35-pilot-takes-flight/ |title= First Royal Netherlands Air Force F-35 Pilot Takes Flight |work= defensemedianetwork.com |accessdate=21 January 2014}} The F-35As for the [[Royal Norwegian Air Force]] will have [[drag chute]] installed. Norway will be the first country to adopt the drag chute pod.{{cite web|url=http://www.codeonemagazine.com/article.html?item_id=138|title=Cold Stops|publisher=}} On 2 August 2016, the U.S. Air Force declared the F-35A basic combat ready.{{cite web|website=Military Embedded Systems|url=http://mil-embedded.com/news/f-35a-lightning-ii-declared-combat-ready-by-air-force/|title=F-35A Lightning II declared combat ready by Air Force|date=2016-08-02}} The [[34th Fighter Squadron]] located at [[Hill Air Force Base]], Utah, has at least 12 combat-ready jets capable of global deployment. The F-35A is scheduled to be fully combat ready in 2017 with its 3F software upgrade. [[Air Combat Command]] will initially deploy F-35A to [[Exercise Red Flag|Red Flag exercises]] and as a "theater security package" to Europe and the Asia-Pacific. It will probably not be fighting the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] in the Middle East earlier than 2017.{{cite web|website=Defense News|url=http://www.defensenews.com/story/breaking-news/2016/08/02/f35-ioc-air-force-operational-acc-combat/87948142/|title=Air Force Declares F-35A Ready for Combat|date=2016-08-02}} On 13 July 2017, UK Minister of State For Defence [[Frederick Curzon, 7th Earl Howe|Frederick Curzon]] confirmed that the UK will purchase a minimum 138 aircraft and a decision will shortly be forthcoming as whether there will be a 'mix' of F-35A and 'B' versions required for 'synergy' and 'inter-service operability' between the [[RAF]] and [[Royal Navy]].{{cite book|last =Jennings |first=Gareth |title=''UK to decide on future variants at 'appropriate time'|date=13 July 2017|publisher= Janes Defence Weekly, Vol LIV, Page XXIX|accessdate=20 July 2017}}{{cite web|last=Jennings|first=Gareth|title=''UK to decide on future variants at 'appropriate time''|url=http://www.janes.com/article/72277/uk-to-decide-on-future-f-35-variant-at-appropriate-time|date=13 July 2017|publisher= Janes Defence Weekly|accessdate=20 July 2017}}{{cite web|last=Haynes|first=Deborah|title=''RAF set to scale back on F35 Supersonic Jets For Royal Navy Aircraft Carriers''|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/raf-set-to-scale-back-on-supersonic-f-35bs-jets-for-royal-navy-aircraft-carriers-5wm0nzfmx|date=24 June 2017|publisher=The Times|accessdate=24 June 2017}} === F-35B === [[File:Flickr - Official U.S. Navy Imagery - An F-35B Lightning II makes first vertical landing at sea.ogv|thumb|Video of a USMC F-35B conducting the first vertical landing on a flight deck aboard {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1}} on 3 October 2011]] [[File:USS America's Test F-35 Flight Operations.jpg|thumb|A F-35B prepares for a vertical landing on [[USS America (LHA-6)|USS ''America'']]]] The F-35B is the short takeoff and vertical landing ([[STOVL]]) variant of the aircraft. Similar in size to the A variant, the B sacrifices about a third of the A variant's fuel volume to accommodate the [[Rolls-Royce LiftSystem|vertical flight system]]. Vertical takeoffs and landings are riskier because of threats such as [[foreign object damage]].Hancock, Ben D. [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/report/1997/Hancock.htm "The STOVL Joint Strike Fighter in Support of the 21st Century Marine Corps"]. ''USMC'', 1997.{{cite web |url=http://www.usace-isc.org/presentation/Geotech%20and%20Materials%20II/Constructability_of_a_High_Temperature_Concrete_Pad_Bly_Peter.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425045722/http://www.usace-isc.org/presentation/Geotech%20and%20Materials%20II/Constructability_of_a_High_Temperature_Concrete_Pad_Bly_Peter.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 April 2012 |title=Constructability of a High Temperature Concrete Pad |work=usace-isc.org|publisher=Geotechnical & Structures Laboratory US Army Engineer Research & Development Center (ERDC) |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Peter |last=Bly}} Whereas the F-35A is stressed to 9 g,Sweetman, Bill. [http://www.zinio.com/express3?issue=368748439 "Numbers Crunch: True cost of JSF program remains to be seen"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304162824/http://www.zinio.com/express3?issue=368748439 |date=4 March 2009 }}. ''Defense Technology International'', February 2009, p. 22.[http://www.defenseindustrydaily.com/f-35-hmds-pulls-the-gs-04088/ "F-35 HMDS Pulls the Gs".] ''Defense Industry Daily'', 25 October 2007. the F-35B's stress goal is 7 g. {{asof|2014}}, the F-35B is limited to 4.5 g and 400 knots. The next software upgrade includes weapons, and allows 5.5 g and Mach 1.2, with a final target of 7 g and Mach 1.6.Norris, Guy. "[http://aviationweek.com/blog/pilot-reaction-flying-f-35b Pilot reaction to flying the F-35B]" ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'', 24 April 2014. Accessed: 15 September 2014. [https://web.archive.org/web/20140727190007/http://aviationweek.com/blog/pilot-reaction-flying-f-35b Archived] on 27 September 2014 The first test flight of the F-35B was conducted on 11 June 2008.Norris, Guy and Graham Warwick. "F-35B First Flight Boosts JSF as F-22 Loses Supporters". ''Aviation Week'', 15 June 2008. Another milestone, the first successful ski-jump launch was carried out by [[BAE]] test pilot Peter Wilson on 24 June 2015.{{cite news| last=Alison| first=George| title='F-35B successfully performs first launch from ski-jump'|url=https://ukdefencejournal.org.uk/f-35b-successfully-performs-first-launch-from-ski-jump/|accessdate=24 June 2015| newspaper=''UK Defense Journal''| date=24 June 2015}} Unlike other variants, the F-35B has no landing hook. The "STOVL/HOOK" control instead engages conversion between normal and vertical flight.[http://www.defenceaviation.com/2010/03/f-35-flightmode.html "F-35B STOVL-mode Flight"]. defenceaviation.com. Retrieved 25 November 2010. Jet thrust is sent directly downwards during vertical flight. The variant's three-bearing swivel nozzle that directs the full thrust of the engine is moved by a [[valve actuator|"fueldraulic" actuator]] using pressurized fuel as the [[working fluid]]."Custom tool to save weeks in F-35B test and evaluation". ''Naval Air Systems Command'', 6 May 2011. The U.S. Marine Corps plans to purchase 340 F-35B and 80 F-35C models{{cite web|last1=Gady|first1=Franz-Stefan|title=Finally! U.S. Marine Corps Declares F-35B Operational|url=https://thediplomat.com/2015/08/finally-u-s-marine-corps-declares-f-35b-operational/|website=thediplomat.com|publisher=James Pach|accessdate=3 March 2018}} to replace current inventories of both the [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet|F/A-18 Hornet]] (A, B, C and D-models), and the AV-8B Harrier II, in the [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] and [[Ground-attack aircraft|attack]] roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marine-corps-aviation-branch-plans-to-invest-in-fighter-jets-helicopters-transports-and-225796/ |title=US Marine Corps aviation branch plans to invest in fighter jets, helicopters, transports and UAVs |work=Flight International |publisher=Reed Business Information |date=21 July 2008 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Trimble |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416041356/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marine-corps-aviation-branch-plans-to-invest-in-fighter-jets-helicopters-transports-and-225796/ |archivedate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Marines plan to use the F-35B from "unimproved surfaces at austere bases" but with "special, high-temperature concrete designed to handle the heat".{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckBlogId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A27103ee8-d867-4e32-a619-92297fa29cf3 |title=About That Austere-Base Thing... |work=aviationweek.com |date=11 March 2010 |accessdate=15 April 2014 |first=Bill |last=Sweetman |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416040527/http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckBlogId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7&plckPostId=Blog%3A27ec4a53-dcc8-42d0-bd3a-01329aef79a7Post%3A27103ee8-d867-4e32-a619-92297fa29cf3 |archivedate=16 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}Diamant, Aaron. [https://archive.is/20120806003330/http://yuma.usmc.mil/desertwarrior/2011/12/22/feature1.html "JSF construction lands another first"]. ''USMC'', 22 December 2011. The USMC declared initial operational capability with about 50 F-35s running interim block 2B software on 31 July 2015.Majumdar, Dave. [https://archive.is/20120724094828/http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6613888 "U.S. Military May Deploy F-35 Before Formal IOC"]. ''Defense News'', 24 May 2011. The USAF had considered replacing the [[Fairchild Republic A-10 Thunderbolt II|A-10]] with the F-35B, but will not do so because of the F-35B's inability to generate enough sorties.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/usaf-f-35b-cannot-generate-enough-sorties-to-replace-a-10-371985/ "USAF: F-35B cannot generate enough sorties to replace A-10"]. ''Flight Magazine'', 16 May 2012. On 6 January 2011, Gates said that the 2012 budget would call for a two-year pause in F-35B production during which the aircraft faced redesign, or cancellation if unsuccessful.Pew, Glenn. [http://www.avweb.com/avwebflash/news/pentagon_cancel_f35_marine_203914-1.html "Pentagon May Cancel STOVL Version of F-35"]. ''AvWeb'', January 2011. In 2011, Lockheed Martin executive vice president Tom Burbage and former Pentagon director of operational testing [[Thomas P. Christie|Tom Christie]] stated that most program delays were due to the F-35B, which forced massive redesigns of other versions.Cox, Bob. "F-35 started with recipe for trouble, analysts say". ''Star Telegram'', 29 January 2011. Lockheed Martin Vice President Steve O’Bryan has said that most F-35B landings will be conventional to reduce stress on vertical lift components.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/06/07/lockheed-many-f-35b-landings-wont-be-vertical/ "Lockheed: Many F-35B landings won’t be vertical"]. ''DoD Buzz'', 7 June 2011. These conventional mode takeoffs and landings cause an "unacceptable wear rate" to the aircraft's "poorly designed" tires.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-17/f-35-fighter-s-tires-wear-out-too-soon-pentagon-finds.html|title=F-35 Fighter’s Tires Wear Out Too Soon, Pentagon Finds.|date=17 September 2013|work=Bloomberg L.P.|first=Anthony|last=Capaccio}} USMC Lt. Gen. Robert Schmidle has said that the vertical lift components would only be used "a small percentage of the time" to transfer the aircraft from carriers to land bases.{{cite web|url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_07_15_2013_p42-594937.xml |title=Simulations Offer Marines Advanced F-35B Weapons, Training. |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022030447/https://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=%2Farticle-xml%2FAW_07_15_2013_p42-594937.xml |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }} On 3 October 2011, the F-35B began its initial sea-trials by performing a vertical landing on the deck of the amphibious assault ship {{USS|Wasp|LHD-1|6}},Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/the-dewline/2011/10/video-f-35b-completes-first-sh.html "VIDEO: F-35B completes first shipboard vertical landing"]. ''The DEWline'', 4 October 2011. to continue in 2015.{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Butler |url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/us-marines-prep-f-35b-ops-trials-uss-wasp |title=U.S. Marines Prep for F-35B Ops Trials on USS Wasp |work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |date=8 April 2015 |accessdate=9 April 2015 }} Probation status was reportedly ended by Defense Secretary Leon Panetta in January 2012 based on progress made.{{cite web|last1=Marshall|first1=Tyrone|title=Panetta Lifts F-35 Fighter Variant Probation|url=http://archive.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=66879|website=archive.defense.gov|publisher=U.S. Department of Defense|accessdate=3 March 2018}} A heat-resistant anti-skid material called Thermion is being tested on Wasp, also useful against the V-22 exhaust.{{cite news |first=Amy |last=Butler |url=http://aviationweek.com/blog/f-35b-dt-2-update-few-hours-uss-wasp |title=F-35B DT 2 Update: A few hours on the USS Wasp |work=[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] |date=5 September 2013 |accessdate=4 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903051254/http://aviationweek.com/blog/f-35b-dt-2-update-few-hours-uss-wasp |archivedate=3 September 2014 |deadurl=no}} [[File:RAF and US Marine F-35B escorted by RAF Typhoon MOD 45162898.jpg|thumb|Three F-35Bs are escorted by a pair of RAF [[Eurofighter Typhoon|Typhoon]] FGR4s en route to the 2016 [[Royal International Air Tattoo]].]] [[File:RAF F-35B STOVL RIAT 2016.jpg|thumb|A British F-35B hovering at the Royal International Air Tattoo in 2016]] Britain's [[Royal Air Force]] and [[Royal Navy]] plan to introduce the F-35B as a replacement for the [[British Aerospace Harrier II|Harrier GR9]], which was retired in 2010, and [[Panavia Tornado|Tornado GR4]], which will retire in 2019. The F-35 is intended to be the United Kingdom's primary strike attack aircraft for the next three decades. One of the Royal Navy requirements for the F-35B design was a [[SRVL|Shipborne Rolling and Vertical Landing]] (SRVL) mode to increase maximum landing weight to bring back unused ordnance by using wing lift during landing.[http://www.nao.org.uk/idoc.ashx?docId=c02da1c8-320b-4062-881d-2c24482459b5&version=-1 "Major Projects Report 2008"]. ''Ministry of Defence''. Retrieved 23 November 2009. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120807073545/http://www.nao.org.uk/idoc.ashx?docId=c02da1c8-320b-4062-881d-2c24482459b5&version=-1 |date=7 August 2012 }}[https://archive.is/20120730180149/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2007/06/15/214672/us-marines-eye-uk-jsf-shipborne-technique.html "US Marines eye UK JSF shipborne technique"].{{dead link|date=July 2016}} ''Flight International'', 15 June 2007. In July 2013, [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Air Chief Marshal [[Sir Stephen Dalton]] announced that [[617 Squadron]] would be the first operational Royal Air Force squadron to receive the F-35.{{cite news|title=Royal Air Force's No. 617 Squadron to fly F-35B fighter|url=http://www.airforce-technology.com/news/newsroyal-air-forces-no-617-squadron-to-fly-f-35b-fighter|accessdate=23 July 2013|newspaper=Airforce Technology|date=19 July 2013}}{{cite news|title=Dambusters to be first Lightning II squadron|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/dambusters-to-be-first-lightning-ii-squadron|accessdate=23 July 2013|date=18 July 2013}} The second operational squadron will be the Fleet Air Arm's [[809 Naval Air Squadron|809 NAS]].{{cite web|url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/News-and-Events/Latest-News/2013/September/09/130909-809-Air-Squadron|title=Immortal air squadron to fly Royal Navy’s newest jets- Royal Navy|work=mod.uk|accessdate=21 March 2015}} In June 2013, the [[Royal Air Force]] had received three aircraft of the 48 on order, all of which based at [[Eglin Air Force Base|Eglin Air Force base]].{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/news/archive/third-joint-strike-fighter-for-the-uk-arrives-28062013 |title=Third Joint Strike Fighter for the UK arrives |publisher=RAF |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=2 August 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701061803/http://www.raf.mod.uk/news/archive/third-joint-strike-fighter-for-the-uk-arrives-28062013 |archive-date=1 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The F-35 will be based at [[RAF Marham|Royal Air Force Marham]] and become operational in 2018.{{cite web |url=http://www.raf.mod.uk/equipment/f35jointstrikefighter.cfm |title=F-35B Lightning II |publisher=RAF |date=26 April 2013 |accessdate=30 May 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2013/03/uk-announces-f-35b-basing/ |title=UK announces F-35B basing | Australian Aviation Magazine |work=Australianaviation.com.au |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=31 May 2013}} In June 2015, the F-35B undertook its first launches from a [[Ski-jump ramp|ski-jump]], when one of the UK's aircraft took off using a ramp constructed at [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River|NAS Patuxent River]].{{cite web |url=http://www.royalnavy.mod.uk/news-and-latest-activity/news/2015/june/25/150625-f35-ski-ramp |title=Navy’s new F-35 jump jet flies from trademark ski ramp for first time|publisher=Royal Navy |date=25 June 2015 |accessdate=6 July 2015}} When required to operate from the sea, the Royal Air Force and Royal Navy will operate the F-35B from ships fitted with ski-jumps, as will the Italian [[Italian Navy|Marina Militare]]. In 2011, the Marina Militare was preparing Grottaglie Air Station for F-35B operations; they are to receive 22 aircraft between 2014 and 2021, with the aircraft carrier [[Italian aircraft carrier Cavour (550)|''Cavour'']] set to be modified to operate them by 2016.[http://www.military-today.com/navy/cavour.htm "F-35B on Italian "Cavour" aircraft carrier"]. ''Military-today.com'', 4 December 2011. The British version of the F-35B is not intended to receive the Brimstone 2 missile.{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/publications/written-questions-answers-statements/written-question/Commons/2017-01-17/60456/|title=Military Aircraft:Written question – 60456|website=UK Parliament|language=en|access-date=2017-07-04}} Commandant of the U.S. Marine Corps, General [[James Amos]] has said that, in spite of increasing costs and schedule delays, there is no plan B to the F-35B.Kovach, Gretel C. [http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2010/dec/08/commandant-calls-joint-strike-fighter-essential/ "Commandant calls Joint Strike Fighter essential"]. ''[[U-T San Diego]]'', 8 December 2010. The F-35B is larger than the aircraft it replaces, which required {{USS|America|LHA-6|6}} to be designed without [[Well dock|well deck]] capabilities.Jean, Grace V. [http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2008/September/Pages/MarinesQuestiontheUtilityof.aspx "Marines Question the Utility of Their New Amphibious Warship"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206002321/http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/ARCHIVE/2008/SEPTEMBER/Pages/MarinesQuestiontheUtilityof.aspx |date=6 December 2010 }} ''National Defense Industrial Association'', September 2008. In 2011, the USMC and USN signed an agreement by which the USMC will purchase 340 F-35B and 80 F-35C fighters, while the USN will purchase 260 F-35Cs. The five squadrons of USMC F-35Cs will be assigned to Navy carriers; F-35Bs will be used on amphibious ships and ashore. Although the Australian {{sclass-|Canberra|landing helicopter dock}} ships were not originally planned to operate fixed-wing aircraft, in May 2014, the [[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Defence]] [[David Johnston (politician)|David Johnston]] stated in media interviews that the government was considering acquiring F-35B fighters for ''Canberra''s, and Prime Minister [[Tony Abbott]] instructed 2015 Defence White Paper planners to consider the option of embarking F-35B squadrons aboard the two ships.{{cite news|last=Kerr |first=Julian |date=26 May 2014 |url=http://www.janes.com/article/38374/australia-could-buy-f-35b |title=Australia could buy F-35B |work=IHS Jane's Defence Weekly |accessdate=8 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140602021021/http://www.janes.com/article/38374/australia-could-buy-f-35b |archivedate=2 June 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite news |last=Butterly |first=Nick |url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/national/a/23583014/jump-jets-on-defence-radar/ |title=Jump jets on Defence radar |work=The West Australian |publisher=Yahoo7 News |date=17 May 2014 |accessdate=8 June 2014}}{{cite journal|last=Kerr |first=Julian |date=22 December 2011 |title=Amphibious ambitions: expanding Australia's naval expectations |journal=Jane's Navy International |publisher=Jane's Information Group}} Supporters of the idea stated that providing fixed-wing support to amphibious operations would maximize aircraft capability, and the presence of a [[ski-jump ramp]], inherited from the original design, meant that the vessels were better suited to STOVL operations than equivalent ships with flat flight decks.{{cite web |url=http://www.aspistrategist.org.au/lhd-and-stovl-an-engineers-view/ |title=LHD and STOVL: an engineer's view |last=George |first=Steve |date=20 June 2014 |work=The Strategist – The Australian Strategic Policy Institute Blog |publisher=Australian Strategic Policy Institute |accessdate=28 November 2014}} Opponents to the idea countered that embarking enough F-35Bs to be effective required abandoning the ships' amphibious capability and would make the pseudo-carriers more valuable targets, modifications would be required to make the flight deck capable of handling vertical-landing thrust and to increase fuel and ordnance capacity for sustained operations, and that the F-35B project itself has been the most expensive and most problematic of the Joint Strike Fighter variants.{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/australian-strategic-policy-institute-raises-doubts-over-abbott-government-plan-to-rebuild-newest-warships/story-fncynjr2-1227128250588 |title=Australian Strategic Policy Institute raises doubts over Abbott Government plan to rebuild newest warships |last=Seidel |first=Jamie |date=19 November 2014 |work=News.com.au |accessdate=28 November 2014}}{{cite journal |last=Brabin-Smith |first=Richard |author2=Schreer, Benjamin |date=17 November 2014 |title=Jump jets for the ADF? |journal=Strategic Insights |publisher=Australian Strategic Policy Institute |issue=78 |url=https://www.aspi.org.au/publications/strategic-insights-78-jump-jets-for-the-adf |accessdate=28 November 2014}}{{cite news |title=Johnston raises possibility of acquiring F-35Bs |url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/05/johnston-raises-possibility-of-acquiring-f-35bs/ |work=Australian Aviation |date=19 May 2014 |accessdate=8 June 2014}} In July 2015 Australia ended consideration of buying the F-35B for its two largest assault ships, as the ship modifications were projected to cost more than AUS$5 billion (US$4.4 billion). The plan was opposed by the Royal Australian Air Force, as an F-35B order could have diminished the number of F-35As purchased.{{cite web|url=http://aviationweek.com/defense/australia-abandons-proposal-order-f-35b|title=Australia Abandons Proposal To Order F35B – Defense content from Aviation Week|work=aviationweek.com|accessdate=31 July 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/news/politics/pms-floating-fighter-jet-plan-quietly-sunk-by-defence-20150707-gi6qxj|title=PM's floating fighter jet plan quietly sunk by Defence|work=Financial Review|accessdate=31 July 2015}} The U.S. Marine Corps plans to disperse its F-35Bs among forward deployed bases to enhance survivability while remaining close to a battlespace, similar to RAF Harrier deployment late in the Cold War, which relied on the use of off-base locations that offered short runways, shelter, and concealment. Known as distributed STOVL operations (DSO), Marine F-35Bs would sustain operations from temporary bases in allied territory within the range of hostile ballistic and cruise missiles, but be moved between temporary locations inside the enemy's 24- to 48-hour targeting cycle. This strategy accounts for the F-35B's short range, the shortest of the three variants, with mobile forward arming and refueling points (M-Farps) accommodating [[KC-130]] and [[MV-22 Osprey]] aircraft to rearm and refuel the jets, as well as littoral areas for sea links of mobile distribution sites on land. M-Farps could be based on small airfields, multi-lane roads, or damaged main bases, while F-35Bs would return to U.S. Navy ships, rear-area U.S. Air Force bases, or friendly carriers for scheduled maintenance; metal planking would be needed to protect unprepared roads from the F-35B's engine exhaust, which would be moved between sites by helicopters, and the Marines are studying lighter and more heat-resistant products.[http://aviationweek.com/defense/marines-propose-rapidly-mobile-f-35-operations Marines Propose Rapidly Mobile F-35 Operations] – Aviationweek.com, 16 December 2014 On 27 September 2018 an F-35B from the {{USS|Essex|LHD-2|6}} carried out an air strike using a precision-guided bomb against a Taliban position in Afghanistan, marking the first US combat use of the F-35.{{cite web|url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-marine-corps-f-35b-makes-first-air-strike-in-afg-452259/|title=US Marine Corps’ F-35B makes first air strike in Afghanistan |publisher=Flightglobal|date=27 September 2018|accessdate=30 September 2018}} ===F-35C=== [[File:Formation of F-35 Aircraft MOD 45157750.jpg|thumb|All main F-35 variants in formation, the greater wing area of the F-35C (left) can be seen when compared to the F-35B (middle) and the F-35A (right).]] [[File:F-35C.jpg|thumb|F-35C of VFA-101]] Compared to the F-35A, the F-35C carrier variant features larger wings with [[Folding wing|foldable wingtip sections]], larger wing and tail control surfaces for improved low-speed control, stronger landing gear for the stresses of [[Aircraft carrier|carrier]] arrested landings, a twin-wheel nose gear, and a stronger [[tailhook]] for use with carrier [[arrestor cable]]s. The larger wing area allows for decreased landing speed while increasing both range and payload. The United States Navy intends to buy 260 F-35Cs to replace the F/A-18A, B, C, and D Hornets and complement the Super Hornet fleet.[http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/systems/aircraft/f-35c.htm "F-35C Carrier Variant Joint Strike Fighter (JSF)"]. ''GlobalSecurity.org.'' Retrieved 16 June 2010. On 27 June 2007, the F-35C completed its Air System Critical Design Review (CDR), allowing the production of the first two functional prototypes.[http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/06-27-2007/0004616904&EDATE= "F-35 Navy Version Undergoes Successful Design Review, Readies for Production"]. ''Lockheed Martin'', 7 June 2007. Retrieved 16 June 2010. The C variant was expected to be available beginning in 2014.[[Rebecca L. Grant|Grant, Rebecca L.]], PhD [http://www.lexingtoninstitute.org/navy-speeds-up-f-35?a=1&c=1171 "Navy Speeds Up F-35"]. ''Lexington Institute'', 14 September 2009. Retrieved 20 September 2009. The first F-35C was rolled out on 29 July 2009.[http://frontierindia.net/f-35c-lightning-ii-rolled-out#more-4226 "F-35C Lightning II rolled out"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731151548/http://frontierindia.net/f-35c-lightning-ii-rolled-out#more-4226 |date=31 July 2009 }} FrontierIndia.net, 29 July 2009. The United States Marine Corps will also purchase 80 F-35Cs, enough for five squadrons, for use with navy [[carrier air wing]]s in a joint service agreement signed on 14 March 2011. A recent 2014 document stated that the USMC will also have 4 squadrons of F-35Cs with 10 aircraft per squadron for the Marine Corps' contribution to U.S. Navy [[carrier air wing]]s.{{cite web|url=http://news.usni.org/2014/11/03/document-2015-u-s-marine-corps-aviation-plan|title=Document: 2015 U.S. Marine Corps Aviation Plan|work=USNI News}} On 6 November 2010, the first F-35C arrived at [[Naval Air Station Patuxent River]]. In 2011, the F-35Cs were grounded for six days after a software bug was found that could have prevented the [[Flight control surfaces|control surfaces]] from being used during flight.Cavas, Christopher P. [https://archive.is/20130121094245/http://www.defensenews.com/story.php?i=6915380&c=AIR&s=TOP "U.S. Navy JSFs Resume Flight Ops After Glitch"]. ''Defense News'', 24 June 2011. On 27 July 2011, the F-35C test aircraft CF-3 completed its first [[steam catapult]] launch during a test flight at [[Naval Air Engineering Station Lakehurst]]; the TC-13 Mod 2 test steam catapult, representative of current fleet technology, was used. In addition to catapult launches at varying power levels, a three-week test plan included dual-aircraft [[jet blast deflector]] testing and catapult launches using a degraded catapult configuration to measure the effects of steam ingestion on the aircraft.[http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4712 "Catapult launches F-35C for the first time"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141017060039/http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4712 |date=17 October 2014 }} ''[[Naval Air Systems Command]]'', 27 July 2011. Retrieved 31 December 2011 On 13 August 2011, the F-35 successfully completed jet blast deflector (JBD) testing at Lakehurst. F-35C test aircraft CF-1 along with an F/A-18E tested a combined JBD cooling panel configuration. The tests measured temperature, pressure, sound level, velocity, and other environmental data; the JBD model will enable the operation of all carrier aircraft, including the F-35C. Further carrier suitability testing continued in preparation for initial ship trials in 2013.[http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4736 "F-35C completes jet blast deflector testing"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218212655/http://www.navair.navy.mil/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.NAVAIRNewsStory&id=4736 |date=18 December 2014 }} ''[[NAVAIR]]'', 22 August 2011. Retrieved 23 August 2011. On 18 November 2011, the U.S. Navy used its new [[Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System]] (EMALS) to launch an F-35C into the air for the first time.Ewing, Philip. [http://www.dodbuzz.com/2011/11/28/the-future-is-here-emals-launches-f-35/ "The future is here: EMALS launches F-35"]. DODbuzz.com, 28 November 2011. On 22 June 2013, Strike Fighter Squadron [[VFA-101]] received the Navy's first F-35C at [[Eglin Air Force Base]], Florida.{{cite web|url=http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2013/06/us-navy-fleet-squadron-receives-1st-f-35c-jsf/ |title=US Navy Fleet Squadron receives 1st F-35C JSF |work=intercepts.defensenews.com |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=13 March 2014 |first=Christopher P. |last=Cavas |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140313221123/http://intercepts.defensenews.com/2013/06/us-navy-fleet-squadron-receives-1st-f-35c-jsf/ |archivedate=13 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite press release|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=74982 |title=Navy Receives First F-35C Lightning II |work=navy.mil |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=13 March 2014 |author=Commander, Naval Air Forces Public Affairs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140313220536/http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=74982 |archivedate=13 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The USN is dealing with the following issues in adapting their carriers to operate the F-35C.Majumdar, Dave. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/us-navy-works-through-f-35c-air-ship-integration-issues-377171/ "US Navy works through F-35C air-ship integration issues"]. ''Flight International'', 1 October 2012. * The fighter's F135 engine exceeds the weight capacity of traditional [[underway replenishment]] systems[http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20130305155514/http://www.navytimes.com/news/2010/11/navy-jsf-engine-too-big-112910w/ "JSF Engine too big for regular transport at sea"]. ''Navy Times'', 30 November 2010. and generates more heat than previous engines. * The stealthy skin requires new repair techniques; extensive skin damage will necessitate repairs at Lockheed's land-based facilities. * The adoption of lithium-ion batteries needing careful thermal management, and higher voltage systems than traditional fighters. * Storing of new weapons not previously employed on carrier aircraft. * Large quantities of classified data generated during missions shall require additional security. In February 2014, Lockheed said the F-35C was on schedule for sea trials after the tailhook was redesigned. The new tailhook has a different shape to better catch arresting wires. Testing on land achieved 36 successful landings. Sea trials were scheduled for October 2014.{{cite news |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304181204579365011426340906 |title=Navy F-35 Set For Sea Trials After Tailhook Redesign: Lockheed Says Naval Version On Schedule |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=5 February 2014 |publisher=[[News Corp]] |location=[[New York, NY|New York]] |issn=0099-9660 |oclc=781541372 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |subscription=yes |first=Doug |last=Cameron}} On 3 November 2014, an F-35C of [[VX-23]], one of the Navy's flight test units, made its first landing on an aircraft carrier when it recovered aboard {{USS|Nimitz|CVN-68|6}}; this started a two week deployment of a pair of aircraft for the initial at sea Development Testing I or DTI, the first of three at sea tests planned for the F-35C.{{cite web |url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84238 |title=F-35C Completes First Arrested Landing aboard Aircraft Carrier |work=Naval Air Forces, Public Affairs |publisher= US Navy}}{{cite web|url=http://news.usni.org/2014/11/03/u-s-navy-version-f-35-lands-carrier-first-time|title= U.S. Navy Version of F-35 Lands on Carrier for First Time |work=USNI News}} The initial deployment was completed on November 14.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=84481|title=F-35C Completes Initial Sea Trials aboard Aircraft Carrier|work=Naval Air Forces, Public Affairs |date=17 November 2014|accessdate=4 December 2014|publisher=US Navy}} The U.S. Navy may use the F-35C as part of its [[UCLASS]] effort to operate a carrier-based [[unmanned aerial vehicle]]. Though it has been suggested that the UCLASS could carry air-to-air weapons, an unmanned aircraft lacks situational awareness and is more vulnerable to electronic countermeasures than manned aircraft, and autonomy for deploying lethal weapons is not under development. With the F-35C as the center of a network of naval systems, it could feed information to the UCLASS and order it to fire on a certain target. Large numbers of F-35Cs operating in contested environments can generate a clear picture of the battlespace, and share it with unmanned assets that can be directed to attack.{{cite web|url=http://thediplomat.com/2014/01/uavs-and-the-f-35-partners-in-air-power/ |title=UAVs and the F-35: Partners in Air Power? |work=thediplomat.com |date=3 January 2014 |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Robert |last=Farley |others=Image Credit: Wikimedia Commons |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525034432/http://thediplomat.com/2014/01/uavs-and-the-f-35-partners-in-air-power/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} [[VFA-147]] was selected to be the first operational squadron to transition to the F-35C in January 2018. Operational testing was to continue aboard {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN-72|6}} at the beginning of 2018. The carrier is the first to be modernized to operate the F-35C. Initial operating capability is expected between mid-2018 and early 2019, with the first deployment is scheduled aboard {{USS|Carl Vinson|CVN-70|6}} in 2020. The F-35C will equip two of the four strike fighter squadrons in a carrier air wing.[http://www.janes.com/article/67250/usn-stands-up-f-35c-west-coast-fleet-replacement-squadron USN stands up F-35C West Coast Fleet Replacement Squadron], by Gareth Jennings, London – IHS Jane's Navy International, 26 January 2017; retrieved 11 May 2017. === Other versions === ==== F-35I ==== {{Main|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Israeli procurement}} [[File:IAF-F-35I-2016-12-13.jpg|thumb|[[Israeli Air Force]] F-35I Adir. It was operational with the IAF in 2018 and performed the first airstrikes with the aircraft type.]] The F-35I ''Adir'' ({{Lang-he-n|אדיר}}, meaning "Awesome",{{cite web|website=The Times of Israel|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/jets-name-is-just-plane-awesome/|title=Jet’s name is just plane ‘Awesome’|date=18 April 2013|language=English}} or "Mighty One"{{cite web|website=Lockheed Martin|url=https://www.f35.com/news/detail/israels-first-f-35-lightning-ii-takes-flight|title=Israel’s first F-35 Lightning II takes flight|date=26 July 2016}}) is an F-35A with Israeli modifications. A senior [[Israel Air Force]] official stated "the aircraft will be designated F-35I, as there will be unique Israeli features installed in them". Despite an initial refusal to allow such modifications, the U.S. has agreed to let Israel integrate its own electronic warfare systems, such as sensors and countermeasures, into the aircraft. The main computer will have a plug-and-play feature to allow add-on Israeli electronics to be used; proposed systems include an external jamming pod, and new Israeli air-to-air missiles and guided bombs in the internal weapon bays.Ben-David, Alon. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story_channel.jsp?channel=defense&id=news/awst/2010/08/23/AW_08_23_2010_p32-249396.xml "Israel To Buy F-35s With Cockpit Mods"]. ''Aviation Week'', 27 August 2010. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}Ben-David, Alon, Amy Butler and Robert Wall. [http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/generic/story.jsp?channel=awst&id=news/awst/2011/07/04/AW_07_04_2011_p22-342412.xml&headline=Israel,%20U.S.%20Strike%20F-35%20Technology%20Deal&prev=10 "Israel, U.S. Strike F-35 Technology Deal"]. ''[[Aviation Week]]'', 7 July 2011. Retrieved 8 October 2011. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] (IAI) has considered playing a role in the development of a proposed two-seat F-35; an IAI executive stated: "There is a known demand for two seats not only from Israel but from other air forces".Trimble, Stephen. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/israel-sets-sights-on-two-seater-f-35-337464/ "Israel sets sights on two-seater F-35"]. ''Flight International'', 22 January 2010. IAI plans to produce conformal fuel tanks.Egozi, Arie. [http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/israel-to-boost-range-of-future-f-35-fleet-220748/ "Israel to boost range of future F-35 fleet"]. ''Flight International''. 11 January 2008. A senior IAF official stated that elements of the F-35's stealth may be overcome in 5 to 10 years, while the aircraft will be in service for 30 to 40 years, which is why Israel insisted on installing their own electronic warfare systems: "The basic F-35 design is OK. We can make do with adding integrated software".[http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/AW_08_06_2012_p28-482027.xml "Israel, U.S. Agree To $450 Million In F-35 EW Work"]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510231649/http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=%2Farticle-xml%2FAW_08_06_2012_p28-482027.xml |date=10 May 2013 }} ''Aviation Week'', 6 August 2012. Israel is interested in purchasing up to 75 F-35s.{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/iai-aims-to-complete-f-35-wing-facility-in-mid-2014-389673/ |title=IAI aims to complete F-35 wing facility in mid-2014 |work=flightglobal.com |date=20 August 2013 |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |accessdate=24 May 2014 |first=Arie |last=Egozi |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525033250/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/iai-aims-to-complete-f-35-wing-facility-in-mid-2014-389673/ |archivedate=25 May 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} On 12 December 2016, Israel began receiving its first F-35Is of the 50 it plans to purchase for integration and testing. Israel is to be the second nation with an operational F-35 squadron following the U.S.{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-readies-for-super-tech-stealth-fighters/ |title=Israel readies for ‘super-tech’ F-35 stealth fighterjets |work=timesofisrael.com |accessdate=13 December 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4891983,00.html |title=Israel receives F-35s, first country after USA |work=ynetnews.com |accessdate=13 December 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/israel-to-buy-an-additional-17-f-35-fighter-planes/ |title=Israel to buy an additional 17 F-35 fighter planes |work=timesofisrael.com |accessdate=13 December 2016}} The first nine F-35s became operational (at initial operating capacity) in the Israeli Air Force in December 2017.[http://www.inss.org.il/publication/adir-in-the-sky-the-f-35-arrives-in-israel “Adir” in the Sky: The F-35 Arrives in Israel] INSS Insight No. 875, December 12, 2016 On May 22, 2018, Israel's Air force commander, Major General [[Amikam Norkin]], reported that Israel became the first country in the world to use the F-35 in combat during [[May 2018 Israel–Iran incidents|recent clashes with Iran in Syria]].{{cite news |last=Kubovich |first=Yaniv |date=22 May 2018 |title=Israel Is First Country in World to Carry Out 'Operational Attack' With the F-35 Stealth Fighter, Air Force Chief Says |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/iranians-fired-32-rockets-at-israel-during-flare-up-israeli-air-force-1.6110706 |agency=Haaretz}} According to the IDF, the F-35 was used in combat for the first time in 2018, has been "flying all over the Middle East", and had carried out the plane's first combat airstrikes in the world on two different Middle Eastern battlefronts. ==== CF-35 ==== {{Main|Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II Canadian procurement}} The Canadian CF-35 is a proposed variant that would differ from the F-35A through the addition of a [[drogue parachute]] and may include an F-35B/C-style refueling probe.{{cite web |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/news/canada/2010/09/01/15213341.html |title=Harper, Ignatieff spar over fighter jets |work=Calgary Sun |date=1 September 2010 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first=Brian |last=Daly|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.calgarysun.com%2Fnews%2Fcanada%2F2010%2F09%2F01%2F15213341.html&date=2014-03-01|archivedate=2 March 2014|deadurl=no}} In 2012, it was revealed that the CF-35 would employ the same boom refueling system as the F-35A.{{cite web|url=http://o.canada.com/news/national/military-will-contract-out-air-to-air-refuelling-if-canada-goes-with-f-35/ |title=Military will contract out air-to-air refuelling if Canada goes with F-35 |work=o.canada.com |date=20 December 2012 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first=Lee |last=Berthiaume |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302041720/http://o.canada.com/news/national/military-will-contract-out-air-to-air-refuelling-if-canada-goes-with-f-35/ |archivedate=2 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} One alternative proposal would have been the adoption of the F-35C for its probe refueling and lower landing speed; however, the Parliamentary Budget Officer's report cited the F-35C's limited performance and payload as being too high a price to pay.{{cite web|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/pbo-dpb/documents/F-35_Cost_Estimate_EN.pdf |title=An Estimate of the Fiscal Impact of Canada’s Proposed Acquisition of the F-35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter |date=10 March 2011 |accessdate=2 March 2014 |first1=Tolga R |last1=Yalkin |first2=Peter |last2=Weltman |publisher=Office of the Parliamentary Budget Office |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302044823/http://www.parl.gc.ca/pbo-dpb/documents/F-35_Cost_Estimate_EN.pdf |archivedate=2 March 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Following the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 Federal Election]] the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]], whose campaign had included a pledge to cancel the F-35 procurement,{{cite web|url= https://www.liberal.ca/files/2015/10/New-plan-for-a-strong-middle-class.pdf|title= A New Plan For a Strong Middle Class|accessdate= 5 October 2015|author= [[Liberal Party of Canada]]|date= 5 October 2015 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151014055323/https://www.liberal.ca/files/2015/10/New-plan-for-a-strong-middle-class.pdf |archivedate=14 October 2015 }} won a majority in the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]]. The new government stated it would run a competition for an aircraft to replace the existing [[McDonnell Douglas CF-18 Hornet|CF-18 Hornet]].{{cite web |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/canadian-f-35-exit-could-signal-wider-air-force-revi-418043/ |title=Canadian F-35 exit could signal wider air force review |last1=Drew |first1=James |last2= |first2= |date=21 October 2015 |website=Flight Global |publisher= |access-date=6 November 2015 |quote=}} ==== F-35D ==== Early-stage design study{{dubious|date=January 2018}} for a possible upgrade of the F-35A to be fielded by the 2035 target date of the Air Force Future Operating Concept.{{cite news |url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/617301/af-releases-future-operating-concept.aspx |title=AF releases Future Operating Concept |date=15 September 2015 |website=www.af.mil |publisher=Secretary of the Air Force Public Affairs Command Information |accessdate=27 September 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.aei.org/publication/20-technologies-that-will-keep-the-us-air-force-flying-high/ |title=20 technologies that will keep the US Air Force flying high |last1=Eaglen |first1=Mackenzie |last2=Berger |first2=Rick |date=15 September 2015 |website=www.aei.org |publisher=AEI |accessdate=25 September 2015}} == Operators == [[File:F-35 operators.png|thumb| [[File:Blue 000080 pog.svg|12px]] F-35A operators ([[Royal Australian Air Force]], [[Belgian Air Component]], [[Royal Danish Air Force]], [[Israeli Air Force]], [[Japan Air Self-Defense Force]], [[Royal Norwegian Air Force]], [[Royal Netherlands Air Force]], [[Republic of Korea Air Force]], [[Turkish Air Force]])

2014.jpg|thumb|One of the RAAF's first two F-35As in December 2014]] [[File:IAF-F-35I-and-F-16I-nf.jpg|thumb|The F-35I Adir (accompanied by a [[253 Squadron (Israel)|253 Squadron]] [[F-16I]] Sufa) on
